PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interest not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public inquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FOR HOUSING IN VICTORIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is he aware of criticism by Mr Kennett, the Victorian Minister of Housing, of the level of Federal assistance for housing in the State of Victoria? Is it true that the level of Federal assistance for housing has declined in the dramatic way enunciated by Mr Kennett ? I ask whether it is also true that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said last week of Mr Kennett:

QUESTION.PARA: I've watched with interest some of the things that at least one of those people has been saying for some months, and I've never taken a great deal of notice of him.
Does the Minister agree with the somewhat cavalier attitude of the Treasurer in ignoring the severe crisis in Victorian housing in this way?

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last three or four months, I think, Mr Kennett's remarks have been the subject of much debate and, indeed, several questions in this place. On each occasion that I have risen to answer questions on the subject I have made the same kind of point as was made by the Treasurer in the remarks referred to by Senator Button in his question. It is pretty clear that there has been a substantial growth in the total amount of money for housing throughout Australia and in particular in Victoria. As Senator Button would acknowledge if he cared to look up the Hansard reports of previous discussions on the matter, the amount of increase compared with previous years is quite substantial. The exact figures are not in my mind, but I understand that the total amount of money made available for welfare housing last year throughout Australia was of the order of $660m. That was a growth, I think I am right in saying, of something like 15 per cent compared with the previous year. Taking all that into account, it is fairly hard to agree with the sorts of implications in the question from Senator Button. Of course, I support the remarks of the Treasurer in this matter. As to the general proposition in regard to Victoria, I would need to check out the information in Senator Button's question to ensure that he is on the right track. I undertake to do that and to come back to him shortly.

—I ask a supplementary question. In giving me that answer will the Minister also inform me whether he has seen or had reported to him the contents of a document of the Victorian Department of Housing which severely criticises the bureaucratic overload and administrative inefficiency of the Victorian Department of Housing? Is that also a factor which he has taken into account in addition to the comments made by the Treasurer in answering the question?
—I am not aware of the paper to which Senator Button referred. I will draw the attention of the Minister to that part of Senator Button's supplementary question.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of the huge number of ships lying idle off New South Wales ports more or less constantly these days? Last month I counted over 40 outside Newcastle and, when flying to Canberra yesterday, I counted over 13 anchored off Sydney Heads. Can the Minister say how many ship days have been lost in the last 12 months? Is it true that the situation has deteriorated rapidly in the last six months? What is the cost to shipowners, to exporters and to the national economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon's question is a very important one because all Australian people are suffering from the loss of export income and, therefore, the loss of revenue to this Government and to the people of Australia. On 17 January the Minister for Transport made a statement in which he set out some of the specific details. He said, as Senator MacGibbon indicated, that conditions had worsened in the last six months. He pointed out- I think he referred to demurrage alone-that these disputes would cost Australia an average of almost $1.5m a day. Of course, the disputes would cost much more than that in the loss of trade; they could damage trade semi-permanently. I think that there has not been a single day completely free of disputes affecting some sector of shipping. A great deal of congestion and a failure to load has come from the failure of particular governments to provide proper port , coal loading and other facilities. This has added to the congestion. The Government regards the picture of the shipping disputes as one of the most serious that can confront us. A great deal of the cause lies in matters that do not relate directly to this Government, but--
—Oh, come on! You are the great industrial relations saviours of the country. You are big on that issue. Tell us about the legislation.
—I will answer that interjection because the congestion in Sydney relates to the Government headed by the Federal President of the Labor Party, Mr Wran. It also relates--
—I take a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is now debating the question. He is not answering the question and I think he ought to be brought to order.
—There is no point of order.
—Well, Mr President--

—I will give the honourable senator a further explanation. The practice of the Senate has been that Ministers have a right to answer questions as they wish to answer them. The only point that is relevant, as I have said on many occasions in this chamber, is that it is my hope that both questions and answers will be short so that more honourable senators have a chance to ask questions.

—With respect, Mr President, although it may have been allowed to become the practice it is about time we reverted to the Standing Orders. The Standing Orders control this place. Question Time has been allowed to become a debate rather than a process of giving information in answer to questions. If that has been the practice it is about time we altered it.
—I will listen to the response very carefully, but there is no point of order.

—Some time ago the Commonwealth Government set up the Crawford committee of inquiry into the shipping industry. Sir John Crawford brought down a report. The Commonwealth Government has indicated to the State governments that it will seek their support. The Premiers Conference recognises , if other people do not, that there is a responsibility for the States as well as the Commonwealth and that they should co-operate in future in trying to ensure a significant abatement of disputes in this industry. There will be consultations with shipowners, unions, interested corporations and individuals in an endeavour to reduce this particularly disastrous situation. I repeat that the cost alone of the shipping lying idle is $1.5m a day. In terms of loss of trade it is very significant and very damaging to the Australian economy and Australia's image overseas.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of the precedent-making decision by the High Court in London last Friday which for the first time gave qualified privilege to a journalist and dismissed a charge of contempt of court against an employee of the London Observer who had refused to reveal his sources as a matter of principle? Is he aware of remarks made on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM program of Monday, 22 February, by a barrister and respected legal commentator, Geoffrey Robinson, that certain self-important judges who conduct proceedings in secret in Australia should take note of the High Court judgment? Further, is he aware of the concern within the Australian Journalists Association over the still pending threat of contempt of court charges against one of its members, Mr Richard Hall, for refusing to disclose sources to the royal commissioner, Mr Justice Stewart? In particular, is he aware of the union' s concern that proceedings involving the liberty of one of its members have been held in secret and that no transcript has been made available to the union, Mr Hall or his legal advisers? Will the Attorney-General see that this star chamber process of contempt of court proceedings is withdrawn and that the Crown meets the not inconsiderable legal costs in the light of the High Court decision in the United Kingdom?

—I am well aware of the problem to which Senator Bolkus referred. Long-standing complaints have been made by journalists about their treatment in courts in relation to revealing sources. The law on that subject has been challenged on a number of occasions over many years. I am not aware of the recent decision in England by the High Court. I would certainly be interested in finding out about it and studying it. It may well have bearing on the matter that Senator Bolkus raised concerning proceedings before the royal commission conducted by Mr Justice Stewart.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise whether it is a fact that, generally, sales tax falls upon the final point of wholesale for non-exempt goods; that is, at the point where the goods are sold by the manufacturer or wholesaler to a retailer or the consumer? Will the Minister please define the exact meaning of 'point of wholesale'? Is it true that the component of freight between the manufacturer or the wholesaler and the retailer should legally attract sales tax only when the carrier of the goods is an agent of either the manufacturer or the wholesaler; that is, the wholesale price is increased by the amount of freight? Further, is it true that taxation officers frequently assess sales tax on components of freight which should not legally attract the tax and that officers are instructing retailers to apply sales tax as the last item on the invoice which, in effect, would mean that tax thus collected would include the tax on the retailer's mark-up and surcharges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall a number of questions and comments that have been made on this subject. I think it could be said that in the generality of cases where goods are sold by wholesale-that is, a sale from a wholesaler to a retailer-the sale value upon which the tax is payable in respect of the sale is the amount for which the goods are sold. The amount for which the goods are sold is usually fixed by contract between the vendor and the purchaser . The question of whether charges for items such as freight, insurance, packing charges, engineering fees, et cetera, form part of the sale value of goods depends upon whether those charges are a constituent part of the price for which the goods are sold. If the sale of goods is ex-warehouse, freight charges may be the purchaser's responsibility and not part of the price. If the sale takes place upon delivery to the purchaser's premises, the delivery charges form part of the price.

ANSWER.PARA: Sales tax is charged on the last wholesale sale, not on retail sales. In certain special circumstances the retailer may hold tax-free stocks so that where he sells the goods by retail he is required by law to charge tax on the fair market value of those goods if sold by wholesale. This means that tax is not payable on the retail mark-up or on any charges relating to the retail sale such as a delivery charge from the shop to the purchaser's home. Certain manufacturers do no discriminate between wholesale and retail sales so that the same price is charged for both. In such cases the wholesale and retail prices are the same and tax is correctly charged on the amount for which the goods are sold. Except in special circumstances just outlined, officers of the Australian Taxation Office would have no cause to give advice to retailers on how to charge sales tax. In fact, retailers are not required to-and generally do not-show sales tax as a separate item on invoices. The liability is with the manufacturers and wholesalers except in certain special situations touched on above.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ILLEGAL PARKING IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. The matter also concerns the Attorney-General. I ask: Do the Ministers recall that almost a year ago, on 9 April 1981, I mentioned here that due to faults in an Australian Capital Territory parking ordinance people who park illegally in Canberra in areas reserved for disabled persons, doctors, diplomats and members of parliament cannot be fined? The Ministers will recall that I said at the time that the situation had become notorious. It is now even more so. The fact that the law can be flouted has become common knowledge. The law is flouted regularly. Why does this unsatisfactory situation still obtain? Is it a fact that there has been persistent delay within the Attorney-General's Department in the improvement of this ordinance? Do the Ministers see nothing incongruous in a situation in which, in a city which is supposed to be the seat of government, whole years can pass during which it is not possible even to cope with the apparently simple matter of creating parking laws which actually work?

—I am afraid that I have no brief on the matter, nor do I recall the question to which Senator Mason referred. All I can do in the circumstances is undertake to find out as much as I possibly can on the matter and to bring down a report as soon as possible.

—The Minister representing the Treasurer no doubt is aware that a great many people are loth to work overtime due to the high tax rate that is imposed upon their overtime earnings. Has the Government, in the interests of assisting incentive and an attempt to stop some tax avoidance, considered limiting the tax on overtime earnings to a rate equal to that applicable to the top of the employee's base salary? I also ask: In these times of high interest will the Government once again consider asking the Australian Taxation Office to investigate the practicability of paying interest on money retained by that office and subsequently refunded to a taxpayer?
—That is two questions. We have supplementary questions; now we have double questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably Senator Georges is a bit concerned because he does not get overtime for all of the hours he works in this place. I think the matter of taxing overtime falls broadly into the category that where income is taxable the operative rate is applied to that income. In some cases this may take a person into a higher tax rate. But I think in most cases the standard rate of tax is the one that applies to a great majority of taxpayers. I can understand what is suggested by Senator Townley. Perhaps it has been considered as a way of reaching people with an incentive for working overtime. I cannot say it is a matter currently receiving very active consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that the matter of the Taxation Office or the Government paying interest on money that may later be refunded to taxpayers has been brought forward at times for consideration. Again I do not suggest that it is a matter under active consideration at this time. However, I will draw the Treasurer's attention to both the points made by Senator Townley.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. In August 1981 the Fraser Government decided to axe the existing Community Youth Support Scheme but because of public pressure was forced to retain CYSS in a watered down version. I ask: Why were most of the 80 recommendations of the CYSS Task Force ignored? Why is the Government continuing to show contempt for the young unemployed of this country by severely reducing the CYSS budget, so forcing many projects to close down? When will the Government begin giving the young unemployed some hope for the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not think much of what was said in the question is a statement of the position of the CYSS program. In the Budget of 1981 changes were proposed with regard to CYSS. I think it is now well known that the Government continued to fund the CYSS program until February, during which time the Government consulted with a wide variety of organisations and individuals. I think the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs will very shortly-perhaps even today-be making a statement on the continuation of the CYSS program. As I understand it, about 95 per cent of the CYSS projects will receive continued and, in many cases increased, funding. It is not a matter of severely reducing CYSS. It is a matter of having looked at the scheme and having established further or different guidelines under which projects may apply for funding. The great majority of those projects are expected to be continued.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the question concerned the young unemployed. I think it should be said that there a number of training programs within the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, the Department of Education and in other places that give opportunities for education, training and retraining for people who are seeking a wider range of employment opportunities. It was said at the time that we discussed the CYSS projects that these were perhaps a type of project that filled a gap not covered by other training programs. In linking the continuation of CYSS with the training, retraining and other educational opportunities given I think it could be said that a good deal of attention and support is being given to the young people who require training and opportunities for employment. Basically what I want to point out is that the whole basis of the question ignores these facts. Perhaps in the mind of the honourable senator there is some confusion with regard to just exactly what is being done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a recent report released on 13 January 1982 entitled 'Pakistan, Human Rights Violations and the Decline of Rule of Law', issued by Amnesty International, which describes a consistent pattern of gross violations of human rights in that country. Is the Minister aware of the report and its claims of widespread suffering and acts of cruelty per- petrated against innocent victims who seek only the right to exercise normal political freedoms in their country?

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister agree that the persistent and serious nature of human rights abuses alleged in the report are in violation of basic human rights, contravening international human rights and the 1973 Pakistan Constitution? Have any representations yet been made to the Pakistan Government concerning the allegations made in the report? What assistance, civil or military, have the Australian people contributed to the Government of Pakistan during the last two years? In accordance with the Government's concern for human rights and in order to secure the effective protection of human rights in Pakistan, what action will be taken by the Government, including any reduction in assistance, in order to bring pressure to bear on the Pakistan Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is aware of the report that was recently issued by Amnesty International on human rights in Pakistan. We are aware also of the legal and other restraints on political activity within that country. On 18 February my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs expressed the Government's concerns over these issues to the Pakistan Ambassador . Our embassy in Islamabad has also maintained contact with principal opposition figures in Pakistan. Australia provides economic assistance to Pakistan in the form of food aid projects and technical co-operation and training. The total value of this assistance in 1980-81 and this year is approximately $11.5m.

ANSWER.PARA: Military contacts with Pakistan have been minimal. Two senior Pakistan Army officers were in Australia last year. One attended a staff course. Other than visits and training, no military assistance is provided to Pakistan. Australian naval ships occasionally call at Karachi in the course of routine independent deployments in the Indian Ocean. We are keenly aware also of the special difficulties which Pakistan is now facing as a result of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. We have supported Pakistan's attempts to find a lasting political settlement to the Afghan crisis. As a result of Soviet activities in Afghanistan , Pakistan has had to provide refuge to two and a quarter million displaced Afghan people. To ease this burden on Pakistan, in 1981-82 we provided food aid valued at $6.1m for the Afghan refugees in Pakistan. Australia looks forward to a return to a situation in which free political expression is permitted under a democratically elected government in Pakistan. We shall continue to encourage progress toward that goal, bearing in mind the special difficulties that Pakistan is now facing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an advertisement in yesterday's Australian Financial Review on behalf of Mr Peter Clyne offering new methods of avoiding taxation? Since the Treasurer has claimed that tax avoidance is one of the major factors contributing to the current Budget deficit, what action will the Government be taking to prevent such blatant subversion of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think we would all agree that there is great resentment in the Australian community against those who seek to avoid paying tax. I think there is additional resentment against blatant advertisements promoting tax avoidance schemes or seeking clients to engage in such schemes. As we have said on a number of occasions, the Treasurer has taken a number of steps that have minimised the evasion or avoidance of tax and we will continue to do this. I do not know whether the Treasurer has any particular attitude with regard to the advertisements which were placed recently by Mr Peter Clyne, but if he has any reaction or response to them I am sure that he will make the appropriate statements. However, I think all Australians would support whatever efforts the Government makes to minimise the avoidance or evasion of tax so that there is a fair sharing of this responsibility amongst the Australian people who are able to contribute towards the revenue of this country.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle stated that the Treasurer had taken steps. Could she be more specific and explain some of those steps to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of those steps have taken the form of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. I think a number of steps are still to be dealt with in legislation. But the Treasurer has announced that from certain dates certain schemes would no longer be regarded as eligible for the taxation treatment for which they may have been designed by those who wish to perpetrate them. I am not in a position to give a catalogue of those schemes but I think those who have been in this place for some time would know that during the term of office of the Treasurer, John Howard, a number of amendments have been made and steps taken that have had the desired consequences. As I have said , he will continue to act in this way. I think a lot of people have been given fair warning that the schemes that do seem to emerge in a continual way are quite against the whole spirit of the Income Tax Assessment Act and its intention to raise revenue for the purposes of public expenditure. When these amendments come forward we hope for the support of the Opposition.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERATION OF TRAVEL AGENTS: GOVERNMENT POLICY REQUIREMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance received representations from the Australian Federation of Travel Agents related to policy requirements that government funded reservations for domestic and international airlines may not be channelled through travel agents except under very special circumstances but must be handled through the travel sections of various government departments? Is it correct, as claimed by AFTA, that concessional, advance purchase and group reservation fare reductions are not being utilised for Public Service travel? Will the Government consider lifting the ban on the use of free enterprise travel agents for official Public Service travel on airlines and ensure that available fare reductions are taken advantage of?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Over a period of two or three years my predecessor and I have had correspondence and representations from the Australian Federation of Travel Agents. I think both he and I have reported to that organisation that it is not appropriate for Federal Government travel to be undertaken in a way that may be within the scope of the representations that it has made to us. The most recent brochure that I have seen contains some statements that could not be substantiated. Perhaps it ought to be said that, to the extent that we could use group bookings or purchase the cheaper advance air fares, we do so. If a government department knew that it had a conference, that a number of members were attending that conference and that it was possible to use a group booking, there is nothing that precludes it from doing so. But the nature of government travel is such that it is not normally conducive to these arrangements. It is more likely that we would have either an individual officer or a small number of officers travelling at short notice to suit the needs of their own departmental work.

ANSWER.PARA: I think most people in this place would accept that there is no particular expertise required to make an air travel booking on a domestic airline in this country. The airlines handle this very satisfactorily. There is no particular service that the travel agents could offer to us that we are not able to undertake with our own resources. In most departmental cases it would not result in any diminution of staff required for the general purpose of departmental work . As far as government departments are concerned the present system is simple and efficient. Transferring in some cases to some new arrangement and using travel agents in a general way would not result in more efficient activity for the Government or a very wide cost saving. For this reason we directly book our travel. If it is possible to use group bookings and to get reduced fares, this is certainly not precluded. What has been said in the most recent brochure adds nothing to the debate that has been going on between the former Minister for Finance and me and perhaps other Ministers in recent years. I think direct bookings suit the needs of the Commonwealth Government at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I direct my question to you. It concerns my suspension from the Senate on 29 May 1979 for quoting from the front page of the Illawarra Mercury of Friday, 25 May, and for having mentioned the words, 'Lies, lies, lies', which were on the front page of that newspaper which I now exhibit. Mr President, you will be aware that the cause of my suspension was referred by the Senate to the Privileges Committee. Subsequently the Senate referred the Privileges Committee report to the Standing Orders Committee. It reported to the Senate that it considered that no change should be made to the present practice and that the President should apply with discretion the rule which brought about my suspension. —In response to Senator McLaren's question I say, firstly, that from this chamber I pass no comment as to what happens with regard to the Standing Orders and procedures in the other place. I regard myself as both a senator and a member of the Standing Orders Committee. As a member of that Committee I accept any decision that is made by that Committee when it is brought to this chamber. That Committee has seen fit still to stand by the Standing Orders that have existed in the place for a long time concerning certain words that are regarded as unparliamentary. I suggest to Senator McLaren that, if he wishes to take the matter further, he may do so to the Standing Orders Committee.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, is about the effect of budgetary restraints on the defence forces. The Minister may be aware that there have been a number of conflicting reports in the media about the effect of the budgetary restraints on the defence forces. I ask: Will formal courses of instruction for members of the defence forces be affected by these constraints in any way? What type of training, if any, is to be curtailed? Can the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that surveillance duties performed by the defence forces will not be curtailed?

—I was asked a similar question the other day by Senator MacGibbon , although the detail which Senator Lewis has asked for differs somewhat. The general question concerns the restraints placed on departments, including the Department of Defence, and in particular the matter of the very large increase in salaries and wages required to be paid in the Department of Defence as a result of the report of the Coldham Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay . These matters are engaging the very close and urgent attention of the Minister and his colleagues, particularly my colleague the Minister for Finance. The matter has not yet been completed. When it has been completed and decisions have been made in regard to this matter, I have no doubt that the Minister for Defence will be making a statement about it or in respect to certain aspects of it. I will refer to the Minister for Defence the question Senator Lewis has asked so that it may be taken into account by him. As I said, no doubt statements will be made by him when this matter has been completed.
—Will the Minister for Social Security be bringing in legislation on pensioners' assets during the current parliamentary sittings, or will it be put off until the Budget session?
—It is still my hope to bring in that legislation during these sittings. When I bring it in will be dictated by when the legislation is ready.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Government's procrastination is having the effect of perhaps needlessly protracting the anxiety of many pensioners, some of whom have only modest nest eggs, for their sakes can the Minister not be a little more specific about the timing of the legislation?
—I do not think that was a supplementary question, Mr President, but if you are prepared to have it asked I am prepared to answer it.
—That is very condescending of you.

—It did not seem to me to relate in any supplementary sense to the question that was asked. The fact of the matter is that I have made a number of statements to clarify the position and to make clear to pensioners of modest means that they need not be concerned about this matter. I realise that it would be desirable to get the legislation before the Parliament, and I will do my best to do so as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Prime Minister seen an article in this month's Australian Economic Trends newsletter by Professor Pollard in which he claims that 'Australians have never had it so good'? Does Professor Pollard claim that Australian families are taking home higher incomes, paying proportionately less tax and enjoying better health and more overseas travel? Does the information available to the Government confirm these assessments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Many Australians will be aware that Professor Pollard has had a career as one of the leading academics in Australia in the field of statistics and actuarial matters. ANSWER.PARA: The living standards of Australian families have fallen dramatically over the last six years.

SPEECH.PARA: In one form or another this broad matter of public importance has been proposed for discussion on many occasions during the life of this Government. It is quite clear from the number of honourable senators who want to be on the speakers' list today that it is a matter which many people still consider to be of public importance. It is put forward today to bring to the attention of the Senate the Government's failure to maintain the standard of living of low income earners and pensioners and to highlight the fact that if we continue in the directions that we are the trend towards a declining standard of living for these people will continue.

In the last 10 years or so there has been much discussion on future directions and where things have gone wrong in our treatment of welfare in this country. But in the meantime the number of people in poverty remains high and the relative position of certain groups, particularly low income earners and some pensioners, continues to fall. Many distinguished and learned people in the community are concerned about the situation. For instance, Professor Russell Mathews, a respected academic and government adviser, at the Summer School of the Australian Institute of Political Science on 30 January last, said in part:

I suggested that the Australian taxation and social welfare system, far from contributing to greater equality in the distribution of incomes and wealth, has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes from the poor to the rich and from wage and salary earner to other income recipients, as well as a major cause of the budgetary problems of all Australian governments and a source of growing social, business and economic instability.

It is this redistribution from poor to rich, from wage and salary earners, plus failure to maintain the real value of payments to those in need of government support and to adjust our economic and welfare systems to changing circumstances which has led, I suggest, to the present situation. If we add to this the uncertainty and insecurity in the minds of people on government income supplements and a feeling of lack of direction in policy, I believe we have a most unsatisfactory situation, a situation which should not apply in a country which has rich resources and riches potentially capable of supporting all its citizens in a satisfactory standard of living.

One of the basic reasons which leads to this state of affairs arises out of the ideological hangups of the present Government. It is the conservative philosophical approach which believes that public participation and expenditure is always bad and to be avoided at all costs and that private expenditure and participation is always good and needs to be stimulated and assisted at all costs; and that public subsidy to encourage private accumulation of wealth is considered good, but public assistance to maintain a basic standard of living is somehow considered bad. For more than five years we have had a series of policies which are in keeping with this philosophy. I suggest we may well ask where it has got us. For instance, the investment allowance has provided hundreds of millions of dollars to private industry with the aim allegedly of increasing growth and reducing unemployment. Yet unemployment has risen and growth is not considered satisfactory by anybody, even the Government, according to its own statements.

Tax cuts which have been given have directed income to high income earners and little or no income to low income earners. In 1978, honourable senators will remember, some $600m was directed to the upper 10 per cent of income earners. Kowtowing to supporters of a system of private health and in particular to the health insurance industry has led to a situation in which too many people can ill-afford access to health care or are forced to pay out too high a percentage of their income to gain access to health care through private health insurance funds. The running down of expenditure on housing has led to an expenditure in real terms this year which is one-third of what it was five years ago.

Together with high costs and interest rates this has led to enormous pressure on an already overburdened public housing sector and has increased the need for shelter and emergency accommodation. This has been a matter of some debate in the senate and the subject of public inquiry by a committee of the Senate.

At the same time the Government has had an overall view that at all costs, as long as certain special groups are looked after, the best means of controlling our economic problems is not to adjust our taxation and welfare systems, not to make reforms but, alone and with a heavy hand, to control-that in the view of this Government is to reduce-public expenditure wherever possible. For instance, Professor Mathews said that policies had been directed almost wholly towards the control of government spending, when the real problem which had emerged was one of restoring control over government revenue. He went on to say:

The lack of distributional equity arising from the failure of the taxation and social welfare systems to operate as intended; the relatively heavy taxation burden imposed on wage and salary earners and the consequential inflationary pressures caused by compensatory wage claims; the chronic liquidity problems faced by business enterprises; the unnecessarily high interest rates associated with low levels of taxes and charges, with their adverse effects on home-buyers, business investors and government borrowers alike; the shortage of capital for development; the reckless running down of the already inadequate public sector capital stock; and the unnecessarily high levels of unemployment, especially among the young, induced by public sector expenditure constraints.

In his analysis of the situation he alerted us to the fact that there are many victims in our society of this narrow-minded and single-minded approach to public expenditure, this failure to recognise that there are spin-off effects in providing the disadvantaged and poor with adequate facilities to live decently. One may add that the cost of failing to assist or do something, both social and economic, about these groups frequently offsets the cost of providing basic support.

I do not need to go into details in this debate-time would not allow me to do so-about the fact that we as a country are not, by international comparisons, a generous country as far as welfare expenditure is concerned. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, has repeatedly pointed out in recent months that on the figures of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development only four countries, three of them poor by our standards-Greece, Portugal and Spain-have lower tax burdens than ours. Yet we still face the problem of the disadvantaged and how to handle them. We argue about gross expenditure rather than about the equitable distribution of wealth in this community. It is this inequitable distribution of wealth and the economic burden borne by the disadvantaged that is raised in this matter of public importance. I daresay that some people who follow me in this debate will use more statistical evidence than I but I will refer to some.

If one looks at the standard rate of pensions and benefits the parameter which people on both sides of this House use to judge their level is the comparison of these payments with the average male weekly earnings. Since 1976, when automatic indexation to the consumer price index was introduced, the level of the standard rate of pension has fluctuated around 23 per cent of average weekly earnings, as Senator Chaney said in answer to a question the other day. At one stage, in 1978 , it was almost 24 per cent. But since early 1981 there has been a consistently downward trend. By June this year it is anticipated, by the research section of the Parliamentary Library and others, that it will be down to approximately 21.6 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is heading down to the level at which these pensions and benefits were in 1972 and at that time there was general acceptance in the community that the level was far too low. The married rate, at 36.8 per cent, is lower than it has been since March 1975. The single rate for unemployed beneficiaries is even lower. These people have not benefited from automatic indexation in recent years and, in fact are worse off. If we add to this the fact that the allowances for pensioners' children have not kept up with inflation and that all family allowances for the first and second children have not increased at all since their introduction-most people in the category referred to in this matter of public importance have only one or two children- then we have a clear picture in money terms of the increasing burden on low income families in the community. Food price increases have exceeded the consumer price index average and essential costs for these groups-costs that they cannot avoid-have increased. The Government actually intended to increase sales taxes on some essential items. All these things add up to the fact that we have a picture of seeming unconcern for this important group.

If we use the other parameter commonly used in debates, the updated poverty line as produced by the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty under Professor Henderson-I suggest that we have no other parameters to use; the Government's committee's attempt to come up with another guide of this type has not succeeded so we seem to be getting no nearer any other satisfactory line to judge than the poverty line-we find that in December 1981 families with more than one child and with a disposable income of $180 a week were below the poverty line. The more children people have, the further below the poverty line they get. Those with four children or more are more than $40 below the poverty line. In fact a family with four children needs a disposable income of $240 a week before the poverty line is barely reached.

We on this side of the House have brought up this fact repeatedly over the years. We have referred to the tables which are regularly produced by the Parliamentary Library, much to the distress of Senator Chaney and some of his officers. We have pointed out that there is a continual drop in the position of these people relative to the poverty line in this community. The poverty line is a useful parameter in judging the relative positions of people and we will persist in using it until we get a better one.

The single parent pensioners, as was found by Professor Henderson in his report , are particularly badly off. They are consistently below the poverty line. For single parent pensioners with more than one child, even an extra $20 a week income would not get them up to that line. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These figures do not tell the whole story, as, of course, no individual figures do. They do not take into account the cost and scarcity of private rental accommodation and the increasing desperation of people trying to find public accommodation. They do not demonstrate the absolute impossibility of most parents getting the sort of assistance that many of us expect our children to get. For instance, one can think of orthodontic care. They do not demonstrate at all the difficulties and the harassment that people face in using inadequate public transport to get care when it is needed, the unavailability of child care and the unavoidable costs of education.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the position of these people relative to the poverty line has diminished and they deserve better. If the Government persists in giving maximum encouragement to those patently not in need and paying for it by depriving those in need; if it persists in the view that the poor have always had to accept more than their share of the economic burden and prevents them from getting out of their poverty by failing to increase their allowable income levels or their fringe benefits cut off points-as the Government does, and I am sure other people will talk about this; if it modifies the means test to favour those with large assets, holdings or cash holdings as against those with small, fixed incomes, as it did in 1976; and if it then procrastinates in correcting the anomaly, for fear of offending vested interests, by announcing, as it did in the last Budget, firm proposals to do this by 1 November, throws away suggested levels of what would be adequate income to be left in fixed deposits of $2,000 or $3,000, and then finds in November that it is not ready-in answer to a question asked by Senator Giles today it was suggested that it is not ready now and may not be ready in this session; if it leaves people in that sort of uncertainty and leaves that anomaly in existence then I suggest that it is not doing the right thing by the groups to which I referred in the original matter of public importance.

It is accepted by the Government and the Minister that there are in the vicinity of one million people living in poverty in this country. It is sad to realise that the same groups identified by Professor Henderson and his colleagues as people in poverty in the early 1970s are the same groups that feature there now. Of course, one group is the Aborigines for whom one makes a special case, but the other groups are the fatherless families, the families with an unemployed breadwinner, large families and particularly the single aged. The only group which has improved relative to the poverty line since then is made up of the large intact families, and the position of that group has not improved in line with increases in the cost of living. It has improved only because of the changes made initally to the family allowances scheme. But worse, if we condemn the poor for their poverty, as some members of the Government have done in recent weeks, if we cast doubts on their worthiness to assistance in the manner of nineteenth century advocates of the political economy, we will indeed soon have a society which is more divided on itself than it is now.

I am suggesting that while we talk about it and discuss it and while the Government is trying to make up its mind how on earth it gets a decent welfare system within the ideological guidelines within which it finds itself, this Parliament and this Senate should at least insist that we maintain the real income of the groups concerned. These include in particular the pensioners and the low income families and those who have to bear the costs of parenthood in times of high inflation. The disabled and the disadvantaged will be able to get out of their disabilities through the provision of income and services at a reasonable level. We need reform and we need debate, but in the meantime we cannot neglect these groups patently in need. To improve our system, it needs reform, redistribution and more imaginative and just methods, but we need more than just public expenditure restraints of the types talked about by Professor Mathews applied in a discriminatory manner. In fact, we need to use the system that we have now to correct the anomalies that are so obvious to us all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome debates in the Senate or elsewhere on means of improving the social security and social welfare system of Australia. Unfortunately, the debates which have taken place in the Senate since I took this portfolio-there have not been many of them -have tended to be fairly light on in terms of suggestions as to how the system might be improved. I regret that, because I would not wish to be in a position of denying that the system could be improved. There is a continuous search, both in the Government and in the Department that I head, for methods of improving the operation of the social security system. I think it would be helpful if those honourable senators who contributed to these debates were as specific as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: There is room for concern when we realise that there is a view that there are substantial numbers of Australians who live at a standard which is unacceptably low. The statistics show that over the very brief period from 1971-72 through to 1981-82 expenditure under the heading 'Social Security and Welfare' has increased in money terms from $1,597m to $11,357m. I do not have an immediate conversion of that figure in real terms, but I think that it is of the order of an increase of 150 per cent. In other words, social security and welfare expenditure in Australia over that period has increased to a level where it is two and a half times as high as it was 10 years ago. Yet we still have complaints that the system is not delivering the goods in a way which is adequate and satisfactory.

I think there are two levels at which the argument can be conducted. Members of the Opposition can come before the Parliament and say that expenditure should be substantially increased, that more money ought to be raised from taxpayers to remove the inadequacies of the system. Alternatively they can say that the system is spending the money in the wrong place and the money should be redirected. Either contribution is a valid approach to the problem. If members of the Opposition are seeking redirection, again I invite them to be quite specific in their suggestions as to how this might be done, from which areas of social security and welfare expenditure it might be taken in order to do a better job in the areas where they say that there are deficiencies.

It ought to be common ground that it is not a matter of being locked into economic theories; it is a matter of being locked into the reality that money spent has to be raised. Whilst it is possible for Senator Grimes, as a shadow Minister, to skate over that essential fact, it is not something which the members of the Australian Labor Party were able to do in government once the reality of government had seized itself upon them, and it is not something that they were prepared to do when they went before the people in 1980.

One of the essential factors that has to be taken into account in determining what can be done in the welfare area, as in other areas, is what the economy can pay and what the taxpayers can afford. It is instructive to look at some of the comments of the now Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Hayden, in August 1975 when he brought down the last Labor Budget. He referred to a whole series of economic issues which have to concern us as a government and which do, to some extent, restrict our freedom of movement. I shall quote a couple of passages from that Budget Speech because I think they help us to understand that this is not a matter of being doctrinaire; it is a matter of facing up to reality. Mr Hayden said:
If wages and salaries continue to outstrip productivity increases, the productive capacity of the economy will decline and we shall all eventually be worse off.
That is a statement which could just as easily have come from Mr Howard. It is a statement of considerable validity. It is a statement of importance today. Mr Hayden also said:

It is not possible to provide more and more government services or transfer payments from the Budget without ultimately having to pay for them through cutting back after-tax earnings via increased taxes. It is not possible to get quarts out of pint pots.

Again, I suggest that is an unexceptionable statement of the practical difficulty which faces all governments. Words which struck a responsive chord for me were made in that same Budget Speech when Mr Hayden said:

Many articulate groups in the community champion their favourite causes and I know that we will soon be hearing from them. I hope that, when we do hear, they will help the Government and me by indicating what alternative expenditure cuts might have been made or what tax increases they would be willing to bear.

I issue that invitation to the Opposition. I invite members of the Opposition to tell me what increased taxes they think we should impose. I invite them to tell us what benefits should be reduced to enable us to make the changes that they advocate. Finally, with respect to this aspect of the matter, I refer to what Mr Hayden had to say in his policy speech when he went before the people in 1980. Referring to the question of welfare, he stated:

Finally, in these six broad areas of family programmes, is a policy we announced last May to give higher family allowances to those families who need them most. Family allowances have not increased for more than four years. They are now worth almost half their value when the scheme was introduced in 1976.

Since then inflation has gone up well over 40 per cent, while taxes increased more than 90 per cent. Given the cost of our other programmes, we cannot responsibly propose a general increase in family allowances.

I do not put that up in a spirit of criticism; I say that that is a simple acknowledgement of the reality within which we all live. That is a problem which is faced by any government in determining what can be done, whether it is for families or for any other group. I will read some more quotations from the policy speech of Mr Hayden. He seems to have said a number of things in relation to this area, of which I heartily approve. He said:

I now want to say something about general welfare programmes. What we can do immediately in the welfare area is enormously restricted by the extent of our other programmes, and what we can responsibly spend.

I say amen to that. There was some confusion in the view that was put forward by Senator Grimes. At the end of his speech he talked about the importance of maintaining the real income of groups about whom we are concerned. One of the major initiatives of this Government has been to ensure that for very significant groups and, in particular, pensioners real incomes have been protected. Senator Grimes, in the early part of his speech, concentrated on comparative incomes; that is, compared pensions with average weekly earnings. I will seek leave to incorporate a table showing those figures over the relevant period.

In terms of the real income as against the comparative income of pensioners, one of the most significant steps taken is to ensure that by the twice-yearly indexation of pensions the real income of pensioners is maintained. Of course, it is true that in a period in which wages increased by an amount in excess of the consumer price index pensioners will see their relative position deteriorate . That is a simple matter of arithmetic. As they see their comparative position deteriorate they will find that difficult to bear and, indeed, that will give rise to a feeling of hardship and, in some cases, to a reality of hardship as prices increase. But I stress the commitment of the Government to maintaining the real income of pensioners at very considerable cost; at a doubling of the cost of assistance to the aged since we came to office, a doubling in money terms. That is a firm commitment of the Government which is aimed at the problem Senator Grimes brought forward today.

The debate in these matters is, of course, brief but I want to touch quickly on the importance of the maintenance of a healthy economy and the control of inflation if we are to do the right thing by the groups that are the subject of this matter of public importance. The fact is that the general welfare of the Australian community is dependent not upon the social security system but upon the maintenance of employment and a healthy and growing economy. Indeed, our ability to provide a proper level of social security support for those Australians outside that economic system-through age, invalidity or whatever-is directly related to our ability to maintain a healthy and growing economy.

I make no apology for saying that it is a very high priority of the present Government to restrain inflation for both social and economic reasons and to ensure that we, as best as possible, maintain employment and a growing economy. Those priorities are directly related to welfare and are not in conflict with the ideal of welfare. I think the quotation I gave from Mr Hayden's Budget Speech in 1975 and his attitude prior to the 1980 elections give further support to that view.

There was debate in this place during Question Time today-although debate is not supposed to happen in Question Time-over the success of some of those Government policies. Let me quickly touch upon some of the achievements of the Government which are directly relevant to the welfare of virtually every Australian. It is surely an accepted fact that in the mid-1970s under the Labor Government we had a rate of inflation which was far in excess of those of our trading partners and which was extremely worrying. In 1975 it was getting up to 15 per cent and there was concern about that among many supporters of the Australian Labor Party. It was cut back to 8.8 per cent in the last financial year. It has, in recent years, been well below the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development average, and one of the key points is that our rate of inflation has been lower than that of our major trading partners.

There has been some upsurge in inflation over the last few months, and in the December quarter there was a high figure of 4.2 per cent. That took into account some Government decisions-the indirect tax decisions and so on and the new health arrangements. They added to that figure, but adjusted for that the rate for 1981 as a whole was 9.5 per cent, which again is below the OECD average. In the context of that surge of inflation at the end of last year, the pensioner and beneficiary population is in the main protected by the the operation of indexation. The fight against indexation is delicately balanced and it would be disastrous if at this stage we injected vast amounts of Federal money into the economy. We have no intention of behaving as the Labor Government did in 1975, with the greatest good will in the world at that time I have little doubt, but with such disastrous economic and social effects. We have no intention of repeating the mistakes of those years.

In terms of what general economic effect our policies have had, the fact is that we have had real growth in the non-farm gross domestic product for the last couple of years. In 1979-80 it was 2.6 per cent. It was 4 per cent in 1980-81, and is predicted to be 3.25 per cent this year. This is far higher than in almost any comparable country and is a measure of the real production of wealth in this country and, hence, of our ability to do other things.

I do not have time to speak at any length on the economy but I refer to the creation of 375,000 new jobs over the last three years, the fact that unemployment for most of 1981 was under 6 per cent and on a monthly basis the figure was below the figure for each corresponding month of 1980. I refer to the fact that in such key areas for the health, prosperity and safety of this country, such as mineral and petroleum exploration, we had a buoyant and successful period as against the disastrous situation that applied when we came to government. The position therefore is that in a difficult world and in a world of considerable uncertainty this Government has been able to maintain a very steady course for Australia. Australia has had a period of growth and increased real earnings-a period therefore when the general welfare of the community has been protected.

I turn now to the measures taken to try to assist those who are not often able to assist themselves and who require the assistance of their fellow citizens for their protection. I have already referred to the innovation of automatic twice- yearly indexation of most pensions and benefits. That is a major and costly reform which provides basic protection to the value of most pensions and benefits. I refer to the increase in supplementary assistance in the recent Budget. This is the sort of area which ought to be explored by the Opposition if it is concerned to isolate those groups in the community who need additional assistance. The advice to the Government has been that the pensioner paying a high private rent is the pensioner who is likely to be in need of assistance, hence the increase in supplementary or rent assistance which was provided for in the last Budget, and hence the redirection of that assistance in favour of those pensioners who are paying high private rents.

I believe it is by that sort of measure that we can do something to chip away at the areas of hardship which exist in the Australian community, and I invite specific suggestions of that nature from the Opposition. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has been accepted by the Senate for debate mentions the maintenance of standards of living for families and pensioners on low incomes. In fact, the text of the matter of public importance which is being debated states:
