It is made even worse by the lack of appropriate remedial action in the welfare area.

One of Australia's major social problems receives little attention. I refer especially to the poverty in our midst. Perhaps too many look the other way and prefer to think that poverty does not exist; but it really does exist in our community. It would probably be revealing to determine when each honourable senator last visited a soup kitchen to talk to the people who have to go there for a meal or when honourable senators last went to visit people who were using accommodation for the homeless, and talked to them about their problems. It is very easy to overlook the poverty in our midst, but it is certainly there. It is difficult, of course, to obtain a precise measure of what the level of poverty is in Australia. I was listening to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Grimes, who mentioned that there are probably a million people in Australia who are in poverty. But what could be called an independent body has calculated that our poverty level is at an even more alarmingly high rate. The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace reported that almost two million people in Australia live in severe poverty and that they are worse off than poor people in many other developed countries. In most cases these two million people , such as aged pensioners, unemployed persons, Aborigines, recently arrived migrants and single parent families, are on social security benefits. It is hard to reconcile figures on poverty like two million or even one million, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, in view of the wealth and the natural resources that we have in Australia. In fact, poor Australians face particular hardships because they are experiencing poverty in a seemingly wealthy society which tends to deny the presence of extreme poverty in its midst.

Low income families in Australia are facing even further difficulties. I mention some of the difficulties that they are facing which are not necessarily pertinent to the social security area. I talk of galloping interest rates, rising inflation and the increased costs of housing and of health. In addition to that we now have Government attempts to victimise further the poor with new and increased indirect taxes which hit hardest at those who are least able to afford them. Fortunately, it looks like some of the Government's latest assaults on the poor by way of sales taxes will not succeed. But when one sees these increases being brought in or proposed one wonders whether there is any real care from the Government.

I will examine some of these factors that I mention. First, I talk of interest rates. Interest rates have skyrocketed recently and even the Government admits that they will continue to do so-so much for election promises that interest rates would fall and so much for the hopes and aspirations of low income families which once dreamt of owning their own homes. Inflation was mentioned by the previous speaker, Senator Chaney. He said that there had been a surge in the rate of inflation in the recent quarter. Well, whether or not there has been a surge, inflation is at an all time high for this Government after six years of a Fraser economic blueprint which was supposed to bring inflation under control. Policies in relation to inflation have been pursued at the expense of employment opportunities and economic expansion. But there has been no halt to the inflationary spiral which further erodes the standards of living for low income earners.

I mentioned the cost of housing. The cost of housing at present is at record levels. The dream of home ownership was probably abandoned long ago by low income earners, but now even rents are becoming an impossible burden to many people because of the cost of housing. I will mention supplementary assistance later in relation to this area. I refer also to the cost of health. I can well remember how in the 1975 election campaign the current Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) trumpeted that Medibank would be retained. Since then the health policies of the Government have been chaotic and confusing. About the only thing that is clear is that health care costs more. These problems which I have mentioned are significant for low income earners; they are significant for pensioners. But for a while I will concentrate on particular problems of pensioners, and this is certainly in the area of social security.

I was fascinated to read shortly before Parliament resumed that the Minister for Social Security made comments in Sydney that pensioners were better off than they were 10 years ago. I was not surprised-although I must admit that I was not too happy about it-that the Minister was hissed and booed by outraged pensioners for the implication that his Government had improved the standard of living of pensioners. A careful examination of pension payments over the past 10 years clearly indicates that increases have occurred in the real level of pensions. However, the rise occurred during the term of the Whitlam Labor Government. During that period pension increases of a real nature occurred. From 1972 to 1975 the real value of single and married rate pensions increased-the single pension by 29 per cent and the married rate pension by 24 per cent. Since 1975, however, when the Fraser Government came into power, the real value of single and married rate pensions has remained static. Certainly, pensions have increased in line with the consumer price index increases but they have remained static in real values.

As Senator Grimes, and I think Senator Chaney, pointed out, in terms of average weekly earnings the pension rate has recently been falling dramatically. I do not consider that it is satisfactory to be able to say that the real value of pensions has remained static, that pensions have been kept in line with increases in the consumer price index, if they have not increased in some respects in line with average weekly earnings. This indicates that if there has been an increase in prosperity in the community which has allowed average weekly earnings to increase, and if pensions have not been kept in line with that increase, the pensioners are not sharing in that prosperity increase. The Minister indicated that prosperity increases had occurred in the economy by pointing to increases in non-farm product. He mentioned that there had been increases in which wage earners in the community had been able to share but that the pensioners had not been able to do so.

Not only were the pensioners disgusted at the Minister's twisting of the facts at the Sydney Town Hall-I refer to his suggesting that increases had occurred over the last 10 years when real increases had occurred over only three years- but also one of the Minister's Liberal predecessors claimed that the Minister's statements were 'misguided and misleading'. Mr Bill Wentworth was quoted as accusing the Government of trying to divide the community by putting the aged against the taxpayers. He said that the real problem was that it had made 'one hell of a mess of the economy'. The victims of the mismanagement, of course, are the pensioners and the other low income earners.

I wish to make some comments about what I have recently heard referred to as ' granny' bonds. I do not particularly like the word 'granny' because these sorts of bonds could probably be used by other than grannies. I have commented in this place on a number of occasions that perhaps we should be considering the introduction of something which I call inflation adjusted bonds-bonds that are available for pensioners or retired people and perhaps even for young people who want to save their funds. I mention this matter because one of the problems that pensioners bring forward quite often is that of the maximum income they may have before they lose some of their pension. If they were allowed to have something like inflation adjusted bonds and if the interest on these bonds were kept at a fairly low level but the amount of principal that they had in the bonds were raised in line with consumer price index increases, they might be able to get around this problem. The allowable income is $20 for a single pensioner and $35 for a married pensioner. If pensioners exceed their allowable income they lose some of their pension.

When supplementary assistance changes were made recently I mentioned that anybody who had an income of even $1 a week would lose some of his or her supplementary assistance. I shall indicate how this system is now working. Last week I was contacted by a very angry young woman. She was protesting on behalf of her mother, who is receiving a widow's pension. The pensioner maintains a bank account simply to have her pension paid into it, drawing the pension out a day or so after it is paid in. She was astounded recently to discover that on the basis of her convenience account she was deemed by the Department of Social Security to be earning 15c a fortnight bank interest. As a consequence she has now received a letter from the Department of Social Security stating that her supplementary assistance will be reduced by 10c a fortnight. Of course, 10c a fornight is not much but it is the principle of the thing that is important. This incident serves as an example of the depths of disgraceful pettiness to which the Government will stoop in its dealings with pensioners and low income earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering a matter of public importance in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to maintain the standard of living of families and pensioners of low incomes.

One immediately would like to ask: 'How low is a low income?' I have not yet met a pensioner out painting the town red. I assure the Minister that I am not in the habit of painting the town red, but that is not why I have not met a pensioner who is doing so. Nor have I seen parents of families with a number of children doing such a deed. It is a question, of course, of those people being under real pressure. One thinks in particular of those pensioners who do not own their own home but live in rented accommodation.

A good deal has been said about pensioners thus far during the debate and I think it would be wise for the Government to take these matters on board. But I wish to address myself to what I see as a slide and a decline in the standards of all families within Australia. Although I say 'all families', affected to a greater degree are those on very low incomes, particularly pensioners. I consider that we have reached a stage where it can truly be said that the Australian family is under threat. Consider the obstacles that our society places in the path of an ordinary couple seeking to pursue their ideal of a family, which, after all is the basic institution of our society. Honourable senators should forget for a moment the devastating effect of a number of other policies and influences, including amendments to the Family Law Act and deviant- type views on marriage by the pushers of drugs and pornography, because the matter of public importance with which we are dealing is concerned with the failure to maintain the standard of living of families.

Let us look at some of the less obvious, but nevertheless subtle and significant obstacles of an economic character relevant to this matter: The dismal prospects of a newly-wedded couple obtaining suitable accommodation; the inability of many one-income families to meet mortgage repayments; the economic pressure to postpone having children; the struggle to maintain living standards in the face of inflation; dwindling employment opportunities for school leavers; lack of support for the family in times of sickness, crisis and old age. Statistical details are not available as to how many families are coping with the sum total of those obstacles and how many families are pushed into a second choice position and into second-best solutions. However, I draw the attention of honourable senators to certain features of contemporary society, including some statistics, which will illustrate that it is becoming harder for families to achieve their desirable objects in the face of those obstacles.

Let us take the deposit gap as an example. It has increased dramatically. The average mortgage required in Sydney is now $53,000. In Canberra it is $35,000. Just after World War II a one-income family in Sydney on average weekly earnings was paying about 17 per cent of its income in mortgage repayments for an average loan on an average house. Today, assuming that it could raise the loan and/or that it already owned the block of land, the interest payments would eat up twice the proportion of income. Naturally, such couples are not in the race. They cannot afford the loans and they cannot afford the land. In the past six years the consumer price index has risen by around 80 per cent. While the net income of an average family has gone up by 86 per cent, net tax paid by that family has risen by 156 per cent. I am not dealing here with the increase in health costs. Because of the rise in the consumer price index, the real value of family allowances-despite the January increases-has fallen by 21 per cent for a family with four children. As a proportion of household disposable income, household debt outstanding has risen from 23.8 per cent in 1960 to 43.4 per cent in 1980. In other words, to survive Australian families are putting themselves into hock.

Because of these and other factors some very disturbing trends have emerged and they require the reflection of the government and ourselves, the Parliament. The quarter of an hour that is at my disposal does not permit me to detail and to enumerate all of those disturbing trends, but I will refer to one or two of them . The other day we heard some faceless member of the back bench-highly criticised by his colleagues, I understand-make the ludicrous statement: 'Why should anybody have children and expect the man next door to pay for them?' One of the disturbing features of the trend I have mentioned is that the number of births has fallen from a record 276,362 in 1971 to 225,530 in 1980. If the trend continues there will not be enough children to pay the fat pension of that particular member of Parliament when he retires. We have to be aware of that trend. The pressure is coming not only from government policies but also from lending institutions. Last year a national newspaper found that finance companies were favouring married couples where the woman was prepared to be sterilised. If present trends continue, it has been estimated that Australia will soon have the highest proportion of sterilised couples in the world.

As a reflection of the reduced value of a single income, the proportion of married women in the paid work force has risen from 29 per cent in 1966 to 43 per cent in 1980. I agree with Senator Colston: The situation can be attributed directly not only to the support and welfare policies of this Government, but also to the policies of successive governments which have also caused some of these problems. I refer the Senate to the 1978 report entitled 'Families and Social Services in Australia' which spelt out some eminently reasonable housing objectives for families. Of course, I await the results of the 1981 census to see how these objectives are being met. The report described current community values concerning family dwellings as including: Each family to have a separate dwelling if it so wishes; children other than infants to have a bedroom separate from their parents; children of different sex not to have to share a bedroom; an individual bedroom for each adolescent and adult child; and playing space for children. They are not unreasonable objectives, but I ask honourable senators: How many families are able to achieve those objectives in view of the factors that I have enumerated? They cannot even get to first base.

I turn now to other aspects of the problem. Late last year a survey conducted in Western Australia revealed that many couples prefer to cut their food bill and put off having a family rather than give up owning their own home. Of course , this shows up in statistics whichever way we look at them. In 1968 the median duration of marriage at first confinement was 17.5 months; in 1974 it was two years; and in 1980 it was 29 months. Looked at in another way, of all the first confinements to married couples, the proportion of couples having their first child after five years of marriage rose from 10.9 per cent in 1975 to 18.1 per cent in 1980. These trends have occurred despite the fact that the latest perinatal figures released earlier this month reaffirmed that the lowest perinatal death rate is in the 25 to 29 years age bracket. Clearly, the two most significant factors restricting couples to a second choice situation are family income and housing.

According to Mr Russell Prowse, the former general manager of the Bank of New South Wales, the number of jobs available has grown by 35 per cent over the last 15 years while the population has grown by only 29 per cent. But in that same period three-quarters of a million married women have entered the paid work force and a great many of those are forced to do so through economic circumstances, government policy and otherwise. Family income is a major factor behind this increase in the proportion of married women in the work force. This has been confirmed by a number of surveys, including the most recent one done by a lecturer at the School of Economics at La Trobe University, commissioned by the Federated Clerks Union and published only this month. The survey reveals that 52.3 per cent of those surveyed indicated that they would withdraw from the paid work force if suitable financial support for families was forthcoming from the Government.

As I have mentioned on a number of occasions, this issue raises deep questions not only of social justice but also of basic equality. Moves for increased family support are often painted as attempts to force women back into the kitchen. Nothing could be further from the truth. The right of women, whether married or not, to enter the paid work force is not ever in question. The principle is that no family should be forced to have both spouses in the paid work force because of the inadequacy of one income. All indications are that if families were given a true freedom of choice, many married women would happily leave the paid work force. One result would be more jobs in the paid work force for those people currently unemployed and in receipt of unemployment benefit.

The issue is whether, in a period of high unemployment, governments should continue policies which force people to stay in the paid work force who have good reasons to be out of the very jobs which could be taken by the unemployed. I do not say that the current Government is solely to blame, but I ask it to look at the slide which has been shown in statistics over the last five or 10 years and to agree with me that action needs to be taken to stop that slide so that the threat to the very existence of Australian families can also be stopped .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish firstly to establish the areas that we are debating. The matter of public importance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to maintain the standard of living of families and pensioners on low incomes.

Speakers in the debate today have talked about families and pensioners in all areas, not just those on low incomes. If we look at statistics that give us the percentage of pensioners who have no other form of income we find that the supporting parents are the ones who are worse off. Only 10.1 per cent of age pensioners have no other outside income. But 72.3 per cent of supporting parents have no other income. They appear to comprise the group within the pensioners system that needs our first concern. I agree with Senator Harradine that the other group which needs our concern is single income families with a greater than average number of children. Social welfare data supports this view.

We have been told by previous speakers, particularly Senator Grimes, that the standard of living for people in these groups has fallen. Perhaps we can look at what this Government has done. I do not think there would be anyone left in Australia who has not heard that our main emphasis is to fight inflation in order to assist these groups of people. It has been said over and over again throughout our whole period of government. That policy is perhaps a little difficult for many people to understand. They still see the prices in shops going up and they wonder what the Government is on about. Let us look at four commodities-bread, butter, milk and tea-to see what happened to their prices in the last year of the Labor Government from June 1974 to June 1975 and the last year of our Government from June 1980 to June 1981. Those commodities are basic foods that have to be purchased by low income families and low income pensioners . The comparison of prices will underline the need for a continuation of the Government's emphasis on fighting inflation. Between June 1974 and June 1975 the price of a milk loaf went up by 32 per cent. From June 1980 to June 1981 it went up by 11 per cent. Between June 1974 and June 1975 the price of 500 grams of butter went up by 17 per cent. From June 1980 to June 1981 it went up by 16 per cent. In 1974-75 the price of delivered milk went up by 34 per cent, whereas in 1980-81 it went up by 14 per cent. In 1974-75 the price of a packet of tea went up by 46 per cent, whereas in 1980-81 it went up by 4 per cent. Price increases affect all low income families and all low income pensioners. I believe that this Government would be irresponsible to alter its course in any way. Yet we get nothing but derision from the Opposition whenever the Government's main policy is talked about.

Let us look at the three groups I have mentioned. What has the Government done for the low single income families? We have increased the dependent spouse rebate to well above the inflation rate and the indexation increases. In December 1975 the rebate was $400; it is now $830. That is the sort of thing we have done for the single income families which Senator Harradine is primarily concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was from a low base, though.

—It was from a low base. We have more than doubled it. I believe that is an area in which we have created some justice within the tax system. The family allowance is another area in which we have assisted large single income families more than any other group, except for single mothers to whom I will refer later. The Australian Labor Party admitted at one stage that the family allowance was of great assistance to low income earners. Those families that were not getting enough income to pay the amount of tax on which they would normally have got a rebate now benefit considerably. Senator Chaney incorporated in Hansard a table which gives all the details. Another means by which we have assisted low income families, over and above the family allowance, is the latest increase payable for the third and subsequent children. The Labor Government proposed increasing the allowance, but it made such a muck of it that it would have resulted in small families receiving a benefit while larger families on the same income would have been denied it. This proposition was put forward by the Labor Party prior to the 1980 election as its main social welfare policy for this group. It made such an awful hash of it that it withdrew it fairly quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what we have done to assist single parents. The family allowance helped this group in particular because the majority of single parents were below the tax threshold. That assistance resulted in their getting the full family allowance. This Government also increased the sole parent rebate from $ 200 in 1975 to $580 in 1981. That was well over the inflation rate and the indexation increases. We also extended the allowance to include not only single mothers but also single fathers, which I believe was very justifiable. One of our most important decisions was to extend the eligibility for fringe benefits to single parents. They were not previously eligible. Single parents are now able to get all the Commonwealth fringe benefits, and, as honourable senators will know, many of the States have tied their benefits to the Commonwealth pensioner health benefits card. We also removed the six months waiting period for single mothers to become eligible, which requirement previously was a great hardship to them.

Only 10.1 per cent of age pensioners have no income apart from the pension. Let us see how that group has benefited. The Opposition has said many times that as a percentage of average weekly earnings pensions have deteriorated. But if we go through the December figures since 1972 we see that in December 1972 when the Labor Government came to office the rate of pensions was 21.4 per cent of average weekly earnings, in 1973 it was 19.9 per cent and in December 1974 it was 22 per cent. In December 1975, after this Government came to office, the figure was 23.2 per cent. Since then the figure has been maintained roughly in that area. In December 1976 it was 23.1 per cent; in December 1977 it was 23.8 per cent; in December 1978 it was 23.9 per cent; in December 1979 it was 23.7 per cent; and in December 1980 it was 23 per cent. We do not yet have the figures for December 1981. So the percentage has been maintained. I deny categorically that the Labor Party can prove that that rate of pension has decreased in any way at all.

Senator Grimes told us that we had no right to abolish the assets means test. He told us that there was no justification for people being allowed to have numerous assets and still get the pension. He forgot, of course, that Mr Whitlam in 1972 promised to abolish any means test on all pensions. The Government at that time did so for those pensioners over 70 years of age, but not for pensioners below that age. Senator Grimes has told us very clearly in this place many times that he did not approve of that. He still does not approve of it. This policy is not now part of the Labor Party's platform. He was instrumental in taking it off that platform. This Government did introduce an income test instead of a means test. That enabled people to get a pension rather than having to sell their assets.

The most important achievement of this Government in the area of pensions was the automatic twice-yearly adjustments to pensions in accordance with the consumer price index. This has resulted in a 50.4 per cent increase in real terms in pensions. When this Government came to office the standard rate of single pension was $38.75; it is now $69.70. It is not a political football any longer. This Government has not allowed the situation in which at every Budget all pensioners hold their breath to see whether their pensions will go up. Pensions have gone up automatically, twice a year. This has given dignity to pensioners. It has enabled pensioners to plan ahead and to know that if food and clothing prices and rents go up their pensions will go up. I believe that this is something that this Government has every right to be proud of. I believe that pensioners do acknowledge that.

We have been told that the Labor Party has promised that it will increase the basic rate of pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. I am interested to know where members of the Labor Party have decided to get the money to pay for this. They have not said where they will get it from. Indeed, the Labor Party has made all sorts of comments about where it will get that money from-from a capital gains tax. But suddenly, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, has decided that capital gains taxes might be a bit unpopular. From that promise in a Lowe by-election speech we have seen a brawl developed between Mr Hayden, Mr Hawke and the unions. Mr Carmichael has said that it will be introduced. Of course, Mr Carmichael has great influence on Mr Hayden because the Labor Party obtains its finances from Mr Carmichael's union. So we will probably see a capital gains tax introduced willy-nilly whether Mr Hayden likes it or not.

The maximum total income before fringe benefits are excluded is $99.70 for a single pensioner and $167.46 for married pensioners. This enables single pensioners to invest $14,000 at 15 per cent and still qualify for the fringe benefit card and their pension. Married pensioners can invest up to $23,000. So previous questions asked in this place-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The inability or the failure of the present Government to maintain what we would all like to see as a sufficient or adequate standard of living for families on low incomes and for pensioners is a topic of deep concern to a large number of Australians, and with very good reason. The plight of people on pensions and low incomes is appalling. Through no fault of their own, they face financial hardship, loss of dignity and self- esteem, real loss of control over their lives and, in many instances, are deprived of all those little things that make life in Australia worth living.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine mentioned that they were not able to paint the town red. I argue that, very often, these people are unable to send their children on school camps, which these days are becoming necessary items in school agenda, they are not able to afford family visits to the theatre or to the cinema and they cannot afford a box of chocolates, a bottle of wine or even a good novel. Their lifestyle is hardly extravagant; their standard of living is hardly high. These people include nearly 115,000 people, both men and women, on single parent benefits; over a million families whose total income is less than the average weekly wage, and over one-third of those families have two or more children in them; aged and invalid pensioners, and particularly the disabled who are also aged; the unemployed, especially those in their middle years who have been made redundant with no hope of future employment; and low income superannuitants. All these people suffer considerably from the fact that their standard of living is dropping considerably.

Pensioners may not, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) asserted in a letter published in a number of newspapers this week, be literally on fixed incomes. But they are on incomes which are below the poverty line and at an all-time present Government low of just over 21 per cent of average weekly earnings. Furthermore, even with indexation, they are never in a position to keep up with inflation since their twice-yearly increases are paid six months after the consumer price index rises which have provoked them. As a result, they are always half a year behind inflation. They are half a year behind the eight ball. In the intervening period, of course, the cost of normal items has increased for them as it has increased for everybody else and they are forced to meet that cost.

I will provide to the Senate today a good example to illustrate the plight that a lot of ordinary people are finding themselves in. It relates to a constituent of mine who contacted me a week or so ago. She is a widow with two children aged 22 and 17, one of whom is unemployed and both of whom have been living with her for the last few years. When she wrote to me she said that she realised that it was not going to be possible for me to do anything about her particular case. But she said she did want me, if I could, to use the figures that she was making available to me to urge the present Government to review fully the plight of low income earners such as she in the hope that after this review some appropriate increase of assistance to them would result. The lady is typical of many Australians who are suffering financial hardship at the moment. She is not a layabout nor does she want to be dependent on charity from voluntary organisations. As I said, until very recently, her children were fully dependent on her.

She is still sufficiently determined to make the best of her situation to seek help from the budgetary advisers of the South Australian Government's Department for Community Welfare. The result of that visit is interesting because that Department came up with the following fortnightly budget. She is in the process of buying her own house. Her house repayments are fortnightly-all these figures are fortnightly-and are $77.50. That is not excessive for house mortgage repayments and it is certainly less than she is likely to be paying for rental. Council rates are $3, engineering and water supply $2.60, electricity $14, heating oil $2, telephone $10 and food and groceries-this is for herself alone-$ 50 a fortnight. House insurance is $4 and car registration, running and insurance costs amount to $26 a fortnight. I point out in case people think that that is excessive that she lives in an outer Adelaide suburb not well provided with public transport. She spends another $5 a fortnight on newspapers and magazines. The Royal Automobile Association costs her $1 a fortnight. The DCW people have kindly allocated her $2.30 for personal expenses each fortnight though I am not sure what she could get for that. She also pays an ambulance subscription fee of $6 a year. The total cost, exclusive of that ambulance amount, is $197.40 a fortnight. Of course, she qualifies for free health care for which, I imagine, she is eternally grateful because I do not see how she could possibly afford to pay for it herself. I think the Senate will agree that this is not exactly a profligate budget, nor is the standard of living indicated by her budget excessively high. Her pension is $139.80 a fortnight. It does not take an arithmetical genius to work out that this leaves a shortfall of $57.60 between the amount in pension that she receives and the amount that the Department of Community Welfare officers maintain she needs simply to exist for a fortnight. Even if she earns the allowable $40 a fortnight before her pension starts to decrease she still has a shortfall of $17.60 to make up.

At this point I remind the Senate that of all groups seeking to enter the paid labour force, women, in this lady's position, are the worst off. They have limited educational qualifications, negligible job experience and are over 40 years. They are the hardest group of people to find places for in the labour force. The DCW officers, having no other assistance to give her, advised her to go to charitable voluntary organisations for help-though I am bothered to see what they can do for her other than perhaps pay her telephone bill. Nevertheless there seemed to be no other assistance that could be given to her from some sort of State department.

No doubt a great many people in the same or similar position to this woman are deeply anxious about their financial predicament and are just as deeply resentful at what they see as lack of understanding of their plight by the present Government. I do not think they are remotely interested in what Mr Hayden was or was not planning in 1974-75. What they are interested in is what Mr Fraser is planning for them in 1982-83. Actually they would rather have had it in 1981-82.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is nothing.

—Which is probably nothing, as the honourable senator said. Senator Sir John Carrick apparently feels justified in making the statement he made earlier today when he said 'Australians have never had it so good'. I think we really seriously ought to consider the question about which Australians he and the author of that article are referring to. They are certainly not the sort of people exemplified by the woman whose situation I cited today. Neither are they the people in Victoria who sought relief from voluntary agencies in such numbers in 1981 that $5m was spent by these organisations in providing emergency relief; not regular assistance but emergency relief. I point out too that 75 per cent of the people seeking aid from these voluntary agencies in Victoria alone were those on social security benefits or pensions. A significant proportion of those people are likely to be men and women on supporting parent benefits. Very clearly the Government's strategy of holding pensions and benefits to the minimum level is placing an extraordinary strain on welfare agencies. Quite clearly too the Government's allocation of, I think, $500,000 in grants to Victorian agencies I referred to a moment ago is just not sufficient to help them carry on. In fact they should not have to be doing what they are doing. In a country of the sort to which Senator Sir John Carrick referred this morning in which its inhabitants have never had it so good, one State's emergency relief bill for voluntary agencies should not have gone up from $2m in 1978 to $5m in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Something is obviously very wrong somewhere with somebody's definition of a lucky country because we are very clearly not all able to partake of the riches of this so-called lucky country. Sure the Lang Hancocks, the Thiesses, the Holmes a Courts and Alan Bonds of this world have never had it so good. They are on the lucky end of the spectrum. They are on the approved end of the spectrum as far as this Goverment is concerned. But if honourable senators ask my constituent from Adelaide how she feels about it I guarantee the answer she will give is not that she has never had it so good. If honourable senators ask any supporting mother whose husband is ignoring maintenance orders and is therfore forcing her, against her preferences certainly, to go on to social security she will say she has never had it so hard. If the honourable senators ask a recipient of a low fixed superannuation payment or ask somebody on unemployment benefits-particularly if they have a family to maintain as well-they will not receive much joy in the reply they get. If honourable senators ask another of my correspondents, this time somebody from Queensland, what he thinks about the situation and how well off he thinks he is they will get the following response. In a letter sent to me recently he concluded:
Remember the people in our age bracket-
He is referring to people on age pensions-
Fought the wars, went through the depression and suffered from poor wages and conditions, and maybe you people would not have had it so good but for the work, fighting and suffering of these people.

I think he has a point. I think he expresses the opinion that a lot of people in his predicament hold. They ask why they should have gone through what they did for a country which appears to be putting them very low on the list of priorities. The Minister in his rebuttal of Senator Grimes said that it is about time that people who get to their feet and complain about the standard of living , the level of pensions or incomes or whatever, came up with something positive. Overlooking the fact, of course, that we on this side of the House are not in any position to indicate anything particularly positive or to institute it, I suggest one or two things: Perhaps the Minister could suggest to his Cabinet colleagues that they make some sort of attempt to increase their actions against tax evaders. If we believe Victorian Ministers and others there is an enormous pool of money going begging from the people at the approved end of the Australian social strata.

I suggest that the Minister and his colleagues do something about instituting a stronger enforcement of maintenance payments because a lot of supporting mothers who are taking social security benefits do not want to be dependent on the State . It is the responsibility of both parents, whether they are together or separated, to share the costs of bringing up their family. If neither of those things appeals to the Minister I suggest that he put some thought into considering a scheme discussed in the early 1970s which suggested that a national portable contributory superannuation scheme be introduced. At the moment the average 20-year-old on average weekly earnings over an average working life of 40 to 45 years will contribute in excess of $165,000 in taxes to this country. Surely it is not too much to expect that for the last 10 years of his average life following his retirement he should get a reasonable pension or superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Grimes on behalf of the Opposition, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to maintain the standard of living of families and pensioners on low incomes.

The first question which must arise is whether that is a statement of fact. Although there has been some discussion of the matter it would be well for me to refer to what Professor Pollard is quoted in today's Sydney Morning Herald as having said in a paper published in the February edition of the Australian Economic Trends newsletter. He said:
. . . in the six years to 1981, average household income had risen in real terms by 5.4 per cent, while the purchasing power of average weekly earnings had risen by 6.3 per cent.

He was talking of real terms with adjustments being made for inflation. According to him there is an improvement in the position of the average household and in average weekly earnings. He went on to demonstrate that a husband and wife who had two children and earned approximately $18,000 a year would pay 18.7 per cent less tax proportionately than they would have six years earlier. On the face of it these are encouraging figures and indicate that Australia's prosperity is improving. But it is important for us to recognise the fact that that does not necessarily answer the question in relation to low income families and pensioners. So whilst there is every reason to say that the Government's economic policies have been successful in improving the overall position of the average Australian, we need to look a little further to see what is the position of low income families and people who are in receipt of pensions and dependent upon pensions.

I believe that the the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, and Senator Walters have given to the chamber this afternoon a series of figures which indicate that, whilst in some cases there has been some improvement in the position of people, in other areas we have done no more than maintain a basic position. I think the summary of the figures which were incorporated in Hansard would indicate that the Government has achieved basic maintenance of the position, while acknowledging that in some cases there has not been a significant improvement in the position. But the question which then arises is: Is it good enough for a country such as Australia merely to maintain the position of the needy, the underprivileged and, in economic terms, the weaker members of our society? I believe that living standards are and should be a true reflection of the capacity of the economy of a nation to provide. But it is also very obvious to the world at the moment-it is being increasingly debated and discussed-that we are living in a world of economic reality. When somebody in the United States of America coughs the rest of the world tends to get the cold. Whatever we can do at any time must be tempered by world trade, world economic management and particularly events in the United States which dominate the world economy.

Australia has an increasing percentage of aged people. We have an increasing number of persons receiving unemployment benefits. We have what has been referred to this afternoon as the huge blowout in the number of supporting parents-approximately a 50 per cent increase between June 1980 and June 1981. All of this has increased the demand upon the welfare budget. I think it is quite wrong for Senator Colston to suggest that the Government has failed to increase the allocation of resources to welfare. What the Government has not been able to do is keep down the total number of people who share the vastly increased allocation of welfare resources. The individual participant is not getting a vastly increased share of what has become an exceptionally great increase-certainly from 18 per cent to 28 per cent-in the Commonwealth's total welfare budget.

Senator Colston was not grappling with the real problem. The real problem is: How long can we continue to provide adequately for an aging community, a community in which large numbers of extra claimants are entitled to and in many cases are in need of some form of welfare benefit or assistance? I believe that the only responsible way to provide for these needs is to ensure adequate growth in the economy. Failure to ensure growth guarantees-I emphasise the word ' guarantees'-that there will be a reduced capacity particularly when we have inflation. It is no answer to adopt the approach which the Whitlam Government adopted in the period 1972 to 1975 when there was a huge increase in the money supply, when very large amounts of money were printed, when inflation was aggravated by huge increases in the money supply and other factors and when, as a result, although increased benefits were made available, the growth in the rate of inflation was such as to reduce the real benefit of the improvements that were made by that Government to a wide cross-section of welfare recipients.

One is impelled to ask whether merely raising the question of the hopes, aspirations and hardships of the weaker and economically less fortunate members of society is not a low grade political practice. It is so easy to say what those people already know, that is, that they are neither getting the assistance that they would like to receive nor getting as much as they need to live at a standard which is comparable with the average within the community. It is much harder, but I suggest far more responsible, to say how these hopes and aspirations will be met and how these hardships will be alleviated; that is, answer the question: Where will the money come from? That question is inevitable , I believe, when the Australian Labor Party starts on its proposals. It is not a matter of political point scoring to ask: Where will the money come from? It is a fundamental question at any level of national and community life. If a wife in a household says: 'Let us buy a new washing machine' the natural question is: Where will the money come from? If the husband says: 'Let us get a new car' the natural question is: Where will the money come from? I believe it is not a matter of poor political point scoring to raise the question: Where will the money come from? Obviously, greater expenditure in welfare must involve either the curtailment of expenditure in other areas or, an increase in revenue, or both. It can come about only as a result of such action. Therefore it is legitimate to ask: Who will pay the increase in taxes? Who will lose from the curtailment of other expenditure?

This afternoon other speakers referred to the cost of various increases in areas suggested by the ALP. What is not clear is whether those increases will come from personal income tax, resources taxes, capital gains taxes or other taxes. I believe that, as Senator Chaney said, there is some duty for those who say there must be increases to indicate how they would provide from them. I support what the Minister said when replying to Senator Grimes. Perhaps the Australian Labor Party would respond to the challenge by stating the full program it proposes, not only in relation to how it will respond to the obvious needs of our community but also where the money will come from to do so. I believe huge inequities exist in the Australian nation. There are distortions and imbalances in the allocation of resources. These are problems which must be solved if we are to achieve what I believe to be the ambition and aspiration of all political parties in this Parliament; that is, a just, equitable and adequate provision for the needy members of the community. To do this we must have growth in real terms. But our trading position is continually jeopardised by what could only be regarded as irresponsible industrial action such as that which caused Premier Neville Wran in New South Wales to say recently:
Some unions have introduced a tinge of lunacy to the industrial front.

Repeatedly one finds that Australia's trading opportunities are adversely affected by our reputation for unreliability in relation to delivery because of industrial disruption. That is one form of selfishness in the community, as is tax evasion, which Senator Haines mentioned. Tax avoidance is another form of irresponsibility which is rampant in the community. Although I pay tribute to the work which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Government have done already in the field of trying to clean up the tax evasion problems, quite obviously it is an area where much more work has to be done.

Another of the urgent problems which has to be cleaned up is that of superannuation. Huge disparities exist between some forms of superannuation, other forms of superannuation and no superannuation at all. This afternoon while the debate was going on I was interested to receive a report entitled 'Social Welfare Policy Secretariat-Report on Alternative Strategies to Meet the Income Needs of the Aged'. This report has just been tabled. The report could well be the subject matter of a debate in this chamber. Possibly such a debate would be far more useful than the continual regurgitation of the one point by Senator Grimes which I have heard debated in this chamber half a dozen times in the past 12 months, with almost the identical speeches being made on each occasion. It might be a little more positive for Senator Grimes to be putting forward some more constructive proposals for reports, such as the one to which I have just referred, to be debated, so that we can endeavour to reach a stage where we can look at how we can overcome some of these problems.

I wish briefly to quote an example. If, in seven years, because Trans Australia Airlines did not make any provision for its superannuation liability in respect of its employees entitled to Commonwealth superannuation, the relatively few thousand employees of TAA caused there to be a debt of $140m run up, can one imagine what would be the total liability of the full Commonwealth superannuation scheme which is unfunded? We just cannot go on spending today what we have not yet earned and what we might hope to earn tomorrow. It is this balance which I believe needs to be achieved. Some people are enjoying incredible privileges as far as superannuation schemes are concerned, from the point of view of the degree of their contribution as op-posed to the degree of return which they get from it.

There are problems in relation to housing rates and the proposals of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which I have not time to refer to. There are a number of matters to which specifically I hope the chamber could pay a little more direct attention. It is not disputed that we should all aspire to the elimination of poverty but sound economic management, real growth and responsible and equitable allocation are required before short term vote-catching gimmickry. I now move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
