SPEECH.PARA: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 February, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are continuing the debate on the reintroduction of Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] ( 1982) which last year were twice returned to the House of Representatives. Although the Australian Democrats acknowledge that the Senate has power to reject such money Bills, all members of that party gave repeated assurances, through statutory declarations and public utterances, that this power would not be exercised. Senator Chipp is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . not even in 'reprehensible' circumstances would we ever block supply or impede a money Bill to prevent a democratically elected Government from governing.

Obviously these statements were made in the interests of maintaining the stability of a properly elected government in the lower House. Yesterday evening , before the Senate adjourned at 10.30 p.m., I was stressing the point that if the Australian Democrats wished to portray themselves as a new ray of hope, inspiration and credibility, they must raise themselves from the indulgences of their party leader in his frequent attempts to crucify the leader of the Government, Mr Malcolm Fraser. Unless they do so they will subvert the party's very high ideals to base and personal motives. Unfortunately, I think the Australian Democrats must be seen as a party that has sacrificed the principles for which it fought so strongly at the last election. Instead, regrettably, it has opted for the easy political solution, what we might term 'political opportunism'. Despite repeated assurances about not blocking supply-I quoted one such assurance earlier-and the great facade of the statutory declarations, the Australian Democrats have done the great about face which in future will be as immemorial as the 1975-type fiasco. They have done this at a time of overrun of Government expenditure and of falling revenues. They have really attempted to put in the boot at a time when the electorate would least expect that sort of behaviour. After all, this sales tax package is an integral part of the Budget strategy of the Federal Government. The Australian Democrats are attempting to completely knock that. People listening to this debate must recognise that the Australian Democrats are denying ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayers the opportunity of getting full and complete tax relief. Last night I quoted figures which showed how the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers were having to bear an increasing burden of the total tax bill. Our Government is attempting to change the tax mix so as to try to provide some relief for people who have no opportunity of entering into tax avoidance schemes and undertakings. It is in this area that I think some relief is necessary. What do we find? The excuse that is given is that it was an error of judgment. An error of judgment on matters of principle are, indeed, a serious indictment on what I might term the first real test of their credibility. Have they come through with flying colours? Unfortunately they have not. They have not had the backbone to be true to their word. As I mentioned last night, this is an essential requirement of any political party if it is to have any credibility within the electorate.

In politics one has to make decisions. Sometimes these decisions have to be hard economic decisions. They may be perplexing to some but, based on the results of those decisions, the electorate makes a judgment. But the situation will become increasingly clouded for the electorate to make this judgment. In future-in fact perhaps for the next six years we could have this instability as a result of the vacillations of the Australian Democrats who hold the balance of power-it will be very difficult for any government to form a Budget strategy. This party that holds the balance of power henceforth must be regarded as not only unreliable but also vacillating to temporary and sectional whims and, therefore, will be completely unpredictable so far as the electorate and any government party are concerned. I submit that these displays by the Australian Democrats in overturning their solemn and sincere undertakings do not make it a creditable party which should hold the balance of power. I support the nine Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention tonight to speak to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills but, on hearing the words of wisdom by the previous speaker, Senator Watson, I believe I should make some comment on these Bills which have been returned to this House by the Government. It is hypocrisy for the Government to place this legislation before the House again. It is a denial of any political honesty before the people of Australia. This Government went to the people of Australia in an election campaign but made no declaration of its intention to increase sales tax and to put it on to goods that currently have no sales tax applied to them. The Government brought in the legislation to do that and it has the hypocrisy to cry about the Australian Democrats changing their minds in relation to some statutory declarations that they signed which stated they would not oppose this legislation. I am not here to defend--
—We have not said anything about going back on statutory declarations.

—Excuse me, Senator Mason, I am not here to defend the Australian Democrats; they can do that quite ably themselves. No doubt the Democrats have thought very sincerely and very deeply about the problems that will occur.
—They are men of honour.

—That is right. They have thought about the problems which will be created in the community, the problems that this Government will create by imposing indirect taxes on the low income earners of this nation. The Democrats have rethought their situation and have now decided to vote against this legislation which is being introduced for the second time. I believe that is reasonable. They should be commended for their action. When this legislation is rejected again by this House, the people of Australia will be able to reassess the dishonesty of this Government which has tried to introduce into the Senate and the House of Representatives taxation measures which it did not say anything about prior to the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important matter to be remembered is that it is the intention of these reintroduced Sales Tax Amendment Bills to place tax on goods that up to now have not been taxed. The government talks about it being an indirect tax. In actual fact, it is a direct tax because it directly affects the low income earners, the pensioners and the single mothers in this community. This Government has no thought for what is happening. It has simply sat back. In Question Time today I asked a question on tax avoidance. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who represents in this place the Treasurer (Mr Howard), said that the Treasurer had taken a number of steps but could not specifically say what those steps were.

In yesterday's Australian Financial Review is a copy of an advertisement which sets out a statement by Peter Clyne in which he says that he will teach people in Australia how to avoid their responsibilities to the taxation system this Government holds up to every one in this House. It has no way in which to combat that sort of tax avoidance. That type of advice is being given to taxpayers throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. What is more, this Government has no initiatives towards stopping tax avoidance. It wants to put sales tax on to a number of items to allow the small income earners, the people of Australia, to pay for the tax avoidance of the big companies, the big income earners and the speculators throughout Australia. If the Government were to do something about introducing a speculation tax, perhaps the revenue going into the coffers would be increased so that there would not be a blowout in the Treasury Budget deficit to the present extent.

The Government says that it is not imposing a direct tax on food but that it is taxing packaging. How many goods on the shelves of the supermarkets throughout this nation are not packaged and will not have that indirect tax applied to them ? This means that people who buy their week to week commodities at the supermarkets with the pension payments given to them by this Government will be paying a direct tax, not an indirect tax as this Government claims.

One should mention the fact that the Government wants to tax books and magazines. The Government has said that there will be some deductions in that educational authorities and people in the educational field might be able to apply for some exemptions from the taxes which it seeks to apply to books and magazines. Again, this Government has completely neglected this area. What about the hundreds of parents, single parents and pensioners affected and the children who are attending the schools? What about the parents who have to buy educational books and who therefore have to pay that so-called indirect tax on those books bought for their children attending schools? Of course, there is the opportunity to make an application--

TALK.START.PARA: —What's that? Two and a half per cent on $10?

—The honourable senator would not understand because he does not have the sorts of problems of the people I am talking about. Let us take a person on $200 a week who pays somewhere in the vicinity of $70 a week rent. This leaves him with $130. He needs $100 a week for groceries and the normal things he needs to keep his house going. He has $30 a week left to educate and feed his children and to transport himself to and from work. If that $30 a week does not pay for the things he wants, he has to take a certain amount out of what he allows for the education or upkeep of his family. So if it costs him $40 a week to do that, he will have to take $10 out of the $100 a week which he has allocated for keeping the family. Senator Lewis does not seem to understand the problems facing the ordinary working man who is on $200 a week, the single parents and the pensioners in this nation of ours.
—They are part of the moneyed class.

—That is right. They do not worry about taxation. As I said before , it was not my intention today to refer to the amendments to the sales tax legislation; I wanted to speak on another matter. But I believe we need to say something because of the dishonest way in which the Government brought this legislation back to the Senate and the way in which it has attacked the Australian Democrats. However, I intend to take this opportunity to speak on behalf of a group of people within our society who have very little chance of speaking out for themselves. The Government's policy of cutting funds to children's services has not only affected all children in the community but has had a drastic effect on the ethnic community children and child care centres for migrant families. Cuts in funding will have disastrous consequences on thousands of struggling migrant families.

SPEECH.PARA: Migrant families are among the most vulnerable in this situation. A total of 47 .6 per cent of unmarried women in the work force are migrants whose income is vital for the survival of the family. The psychological stability and the productivity of these women depend on the availability of adequate child care and the knowledge that their children will be well cared for. Because child care or adequate facilities are not available stress builds up within the family. This stress, along with the pressure brought about by migration, cultural difference and cultural conflict, builds up problems which can result in child abuse developing in parts of the ethnic community. The Government needs to understand and to recognise the problems facing migrant families with young children. The special stresses on migrants need to be investigated. Cutbacks in child welfare funding by the razor gang have created problems and stress within ethnic families and their children. This development of stress has brought about a position in which child abuse exists within the ethnic community in Australia. The Government and the community should try to recognise some of the related factors, the problems facing migrant families with young children-some of the factors that lead parents to become involved in physical and emotional abuse of their children. I refer to stress caused by migration, cultural differences, cultural conflict, lack of child care and lack of day long child care facilities from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m.

One of the major reasons for families migrating to Australia is economic advancement. This carries with it a strong belief in the opportunity for a good education and better life for their children. From the post-war period to the early 1970s Australian governments encouraged large scale migration to Australia . However, little planning was carried out to assist the new settlers to integrate into the Australian society. Migrants were expected to assimilate. Their special needs were overlooked. In the early 1970s assistance such as interpreting, English classes and welfare services for ethnic communities was commenced. This was followed by the development in the mid-1970s of institutional changes, including the establishment of bodies such as the Ethnic Affairs Commission of New South Wales and the ethnic community councils. In addition, conferences dealing with specific issues such as migrant women, health and refugees began to focus attention on the specific needs of migrant communities and on the problem of family stress and the impact on children. Matters of child abuse and punishment are recent developments in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would do better if you did not read it.

—I have copious notes. Attention to the impact on the migrant community is only now beginning. Migration brings upon families many unexpected results which create varying degrees of stress. Stress is caused by the lack of English. This isolates men and women in the work force and in society, and communication with children becomes difficult once children begin to speak English. There is also the loss of extended families which could usually be relied upon for support in child rearing and social life. The changed lifestyle, with both parents often working long hours doing manual labour in a factory, also creates stress. Isolation is felt by many women who stay at home. Role reversal is becoming as common as unemployment. The number of work accidents increases amongst migrant men. Women are assuming the responsiblity of being main bread winners in the family, causing serious stress for the men.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator JONES

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting, unexpected reasons create varying degrees of stress. Many of these stresses remain hidden in the family and are not accessible to the community and welfare workers. In many cases of child abuse the existence and relevance of these factors have emerged only after considerable investigation of the family's way of life. One of the real needs for migrant families is support in child rearing and assistance with social life. When other cultures come into conflict with our Australian way of life it is the migrant and the Aboriginal cultures that are left with feelings of shame, doubt, resentment and inferiority. Despite the rhetoric of multiculturalism it is always clear to the migrants that the pressure is on their values and traditions. This is borne out by the evidence. It shows the importance and the need for child care facilities to this section of the community.

INTERJECT.PARA: Examples of need are shown by the problems that have been created. There are many instances where migrant families leave children in their beds or in the home alone while the parents are at work. This occurs not because the parents have no understanding of the need for child care or are punishing the child deliberately. The lack of child care facilities, the high cost of the existing facilities, little knowledge of alternative services plus the lack of extended family support lead to these choices. Is this abuse or a deficiency in our social structure? This problem begins to develop before the migrant leaves his own country. It is brought about by the wrong information being given to prospective migrants. Pamphlets issued in Spain recently by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs carried, and still carry, the information 'that Australia has adequate child care facilities'. Another information pamphlet entitled 'Education in Australia'-I think the first edition was printed in 1968- states:

In Australia in most of the highly populated industrial cities there are many varieties of child-care places such as pre-school centres, creches, family day care centres, full day and part-time centres and even holiday houses.
In actual fact there is a desperate shortage of all kinds of child care facilities and particularly those that cater for working mothers.

For some families the choice is extreme. They send their children home to relatives overseas. Recent statistics are not available but research by a Turkish community worker found that between 1970 and 1972 of more than 600 Turkish children born in New South Wales at least half had been sent back to Turkey. Nazli Munir, a social worker in New South Wales, said that in the early 1980s there was evidence of the disastrous effects that this separation could have on families once the children again were united with their parents. Children become attached to their grandparents and relatives overseas. At the most crucial stage of early development it is a relative and not the parent who becomes the dominant figure in the child's life. All of a sudden the children are separated from their relatives whth whom they have built a strong bond. They are united or reunited with their parents, brothers or sisters whom they do not know. They have no knowledge of English and have to adjust to a life in a totally new country. Whatever the age of the child, adjustment to a new country and family while grieving the loss of relatives overseas causes much emotional stress. Often parents do not understand the process of change. Their image of a loving child may be shattered.

In the case of one Turkish family the first-born-a girl-was sent to Turkey when she was two months old. When she was almost two years old her mother gave birth to another daughter. Having decided that the mother would give up work to care for the child the father went to Turkey to bring back the first child, the daughter. The daughter got to know her father over a few months before leaving for Australia and became attached to him. She grieved for her grandparents, uncles and aunts in Turkey. But she showed little feeling towards her mother and was extremely jealous of the baby. Within the first month of her arrival in Australia the family sought help. The mother was feeling desperate that she could not make her elder daughter love her and at times came very close to hitting her. She felt also that she did not have the same amount of feeling for the first child as she had for the second. Her solution was a determination to send the daughter back to Turkey.

In a number of counselling sessions the mother was asked to be a little more patient. It was suggested that perhaps her daughter could be put into a family day care centre for a few days a week to give her mother the necessary break. The mother was warned that if she sent the child back to Turkey she would be jeopardising any hope of building a mother-daughter relationship with the child in the future. It was pointed out also that if her daughter was then brought back to Australia she could suffer serious emotional trauma. The effects of the separation from her grandparents were clearly visible in the child's behaviour- she needed attention and cried if the person paying her attention left. A second such dramatic separation would cause only further distress. The family then decided to send the child once again to Turkey. It is over two years since she left Australia. Since then, her mother has gone back to work and the family has bought a house. The mother is planning to bring the daughter back to Australia again. The mother, I might say, is not an abuser but a victim of our social system-a system that encourages and often forces mothers to work to survive but provides no decent system of child care for the majority of working women.

There has been a drop in the number of families sending children overseas. There has been a number of factors, none of which is adequate child care. I believe families have been able to become a part of the community's network. Increased unemployment leads to women being left at home to look after the children. What happens overseas does not help the conflict that has been built between the children and the mother. Conflict in Lebanon, economic conditions in Turkey and the problem of families not being able to send money overseas have not helped. Because of economic conditions people have had to try to find other solutions. I am informed that further research carried out last year shows that of 40 Turkish mothers who had pre-school children two were considering sending their children overseas because it was the only alternative they saw to the child care problem. The razor gang cuts have decreased child care funding further. This makes it more difficult for migrant families in Australia. So, the problem of sending children overseas will become an even worse problem. Extra finance is required, not less.

For migrant families the long day care centres are vital. One cannot put a child into a child care centre when it is open only from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Long day care centres are required. I think the Government needs to provide the sort of finance that would allow the provision of these sorts of centres. That would allow migrant families to place their children in centres that are open from 7 a .m. to 4 p.m. at least and allow the parents to work and obtain care for their children so that the parents can gain the economic responsibility and growth that they know will come to them by working hard in this country of ours. I think it is unfair that the Government has not provided those sorts of facilities for the migrant children in this country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the first reading of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills. I offer no apology for speaking in this first reading debate on the Bills but I intend to speak on them in relation to questions of principle. I hope that in due course I shall get an opportunity to speak in the second reading debate on the same subject, when I shall deal at some length with the allegations which have been made here from time to time that these Bills are regressive and a terrible punishment for the low income earners of Australia. I hope that I will be able to persuade the Senate that that is absolute nonsense, that in fact, quite to the contrary, the Bills are not regressive but impose a decent tax on those who have large incomes and spend them and that the poorer income earners of Australia will not suffer anything like the punishments that allegedly will be inflicted by this legislation. That is not the subject with which I wish to deal in this first reading debate. I wish to talk of questions of principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I turn to the Australian Labor Party. After the 1975 election we heard long speeches being repeated by various members of the Labor Party, both within and outside the Parliament, about the alleged reprehensible conduct of honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber-in other words, the senators who voted against the money Bills in the Senate. Let me make my position quite clear. I think they did the right thing. I have no doubt whatsoever that the Senate has the power to reject money Bills. That is laid down in the Constitution. I might say that I would like the Constitution to be altered so that if the Senate does reject money Bills the Government will have the opportunity to take the Senate, not just the House of Representatives, to the people. But that is another matter. The speeches from 1975 to 1980 about the alleged reprehensible conduct of people on our side of the chamber were continued with much ferocity. In fact, the ALP pledged itself to seek constitutional amendment to ensure that the Senate would have no power 'to reject, defer or otherwise block money Bills'. I repeat the words 'money Bills'.

After the election of 1980, the ALP, of course, as it always does when it is defeated in an election, went into a state of shock. About six months after the election we started to hear a different tune. We started to hear ALP leaders talking like what I would call devious lawyers about some fine distinction between so-called money Bills and Supply Bills-between major Supply and Appropriation Bills on the one hand and so-called lesser money Bills on the other hand, between money Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government and those which are not. I could not help being reminded of the allegations that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had changed his tune between 1974 and 1975. It was quite clear to all those who were following events that the Labor Party was in the process of changing its tune. In fact it was trying to find some way to justify the blocking of Supply. Let us look at some of the things said by Senator Evans, for example. I shall quote from a speech which he made to the National Conference of Labor Lawyers as late as July 1981, when he advised against blocking Supply.
He said:
. . . the fact that constitutional and democratic principles were torn up in 1975-
I do not agree with that statement, of course, but that is apparently what he believed-
is no excuse for anyone doing it again . . . I believe that our credibility and self-respect as a movement depends on us being more principled than our opponents . . .

As I said, that statement was made as late as July 1981. Then we saw Senators Evans beginning to back down, no doubt under the influence of various members of the Caucus. He is reported in the Hansard for 20 August 1981 as having said:
The relevant distinction that we have been talking our way through-
They are interesting words, Mr President. It is clear from the use of the word ' through' that members of the Labor Party were trying to talk themselves through to a particular position. He stated:

The relevant distinction that we have been talking our way through . . . is that between . . . on the one hand Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government . . . and, on the other, those which do not satisfy that description.

He went on to talk about lesser money Bills and Bills which were essential to the survival of the Government. The people of this nation are not fools. They know what the Labor Party was trying to do. It was trying to find some way to justify a change in its position, the position which it had claimed was based on one of those principles which it had been protesting about throughout the period from 1975 to 1980. Senator Evans, in that speech of 20 August 1981, said:
. . . whenever I or anyone else has used those kinds of expressions-
He was referring to expressions such as 'blocking of Supply', 'blocking of money Bills' and 'blocking of Budgets'--

in all the debates that have taken place since 1974 and 1975 we have been using them in the context of the events of 1974 and 1975 when what was at issue was a particular category of Bills . . . which were on any view crucial to the continued survival, the continued existence of the Government of the day.

It is clear that he was saying: 'We are now talking about something different'. I was reminded of what Humpty Dumpty said in Alice through the Looking Glass. ' When I use a word', Humpty Dumpty said in a rather scornful tone, 'it means just what I choose it to mean-neither more nor less'. One can see the scornful Senator Evans making just such a distinction and saying: 'When I use a word it means what I mean and not necessarily what it means in the dictionary and to everyone else'. Having made his fine distinction, Senator Evans went further and started to renege even on those commitments which he had made. He was reported in the Age of 11 November as having said at a news conference:

I wouldn't want to put a time limit or try to identify the circumstances which might lead us to change our mind. All I can say is that there is considerable pressure within the party-in the parliamentary and the Labor Party at large-to adopt a more robust attitude on these issues, to pick a head when we see it, to do unto others precisely what they did to us in 1975 and not to accept any of the limitations of principle that we have accepted so far.

Surely that is a devastating admission. Later in the conference he was asked whether he would rule out the possibility of Labor being prepared to reject Supply in the life of this Government. Senator Evans said:
I am not either ruling it out or accepting it.

Clearly the ALP leaders have irretrievably compromised themselves and their so- called principles. Senator Evans set himself up in this chamber as a constitutional authority of principle but in fact he has now been exposed as a hack lawyer on Caucus decisions who is able to pick up a brief on either side of the debate and put some sort of a front on it, throwing all his so-called principles to the wind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Liberal Party believe in blocking money Bills or doesn 't it?

—Yes. There is no question about that. Senator Siddons asked: Does the Liberal Party believe in blocking money Bills or not? There is no question about that. I stand right behind what Mr Odgers, the former Clerk of the Senate, said in his book about that. Let there be no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Australian Democrats. I was terribly tempted to talk with regard to the Democrats about political opportunism at its worst. That has been suggested by many, both within this Parliament and outside it. Really, I say sincerely to the Democrats that that was my first reaction when I read what Senator Chipp was saying: 'We are now going to vote against these Bills'. At first I could not believe it because I have always thought that Senator Chipp is a man of principle. Then I thought: 'He is now exposed as a political opportunist of the worst kind'. I find that extremely difficult to believe because I have seen Senator Chipp within the Liberal Party for many years. I was associated with him on one or two committees of the Liberal Party and I have seen him in this chamber. I just could not believe it.

But last night, when Senator Siddons was talking in this chamber, the penny dropped. I must say that I offer to the Democrats my sincere sympathy. The answer just came to me last night. When the Democrats were elected to this chamber they were saying: 'We are not going to say what we will do about any matter in particular. We will listen to the arguments and be persuaded'. When that is first said one thinks that is a reasonable thing for the Democrats to do . It sounds simple. But once one realises what happens in the Parliament one realises that the real problem is that they have opened themselves to the lobbyists. That means that if the lobbyists, who want to be able to work on them , can send them enough correspondence, enough petitions and enough materials, the lobbyists will win the argument. It became clear to me that since the Democrats decided last year to defer this legislation and said: 'We will deal with it again when it is brought up in February', they have been inundated with lobbying material. I feel sorry for them because I know what it is like. Of course, I feel even sorrier for them because of what the future will bring. Until now they have been lobbied only by people from one side, those who are against sales tax, and, of course, everyone is against any sort of tax. There is no doubt about that. But wait until they are lobbied by the social reformers. The social reformers will lobby them all around the clock from all sides. They will be lobbied by those who are totally in favour, those who are moderately in favour, those who are slightly in favour, by those who are grey, those who are black and white, those who want this change and those who want that change. Truck load after truck load of letters will be delivered to them as they go into the matters which this Parliament will be debating in due course. I offer to the Democrats my sincerest sympathy. I can understand. Let us listen to what they had to say. On 26 August 1981 in this chamber Senator Mason said-and who would doubt that he was genuine:
I am one of those who regrets the events of 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still do.
—Senator Mason says: 'I still do'. I continue to quote Senator Mason:

SPEECH.PARA: It was something that should never have happened. The reason for making our pledge is that we do not want to see it happen again. We know that the people of this country do not want it to happen again. They do not want any meddling or messing around which will produce the slightest likelihood of its happening again.
Later in the same speech he said:
I return to the question that arises: Can we mess around with the Budget a little . . .
Those are interesting words. Can we just knock off a little bit of a money Bill? We are not sure what a little bit is. To continue:
Can we mess around with the Budget a little and if so, how much? Clearly, to reject Bills which would cost the Government a billion dollars would be going too far.
So, he puts a limit on it. A billion dollars is too far. To continue:

I assume that Labor senators would agree with me; I do not know . . . It really comes back to a matter of degree, does it not? Clearly the Senate has the right to alter the Budget a little. It has an equal right to alter it a great deal.
I suggest that it has neither of those and that in fact it has a right to reject . To continue:
I suggest that the difference is merely quantitative. That is a dangerous path that would lead the way to the re-enactment of the events of 1975 . . .
Later, in the same speech, Senator Tate put to Senator Mason:
You can reject it when it comes back here.
That is what we are on about tonight; it has come back here. Senator Tate put that proposition to Senator Mason and Senator Mason responded:

True; I will go on to that. We are facing that one. We are not dodging that one . True to our word, if the Government takes the reprehensible step of rejecting that request the Australian Democrats will not oppose the passage of that Budget legislation through the Senate. That is definite. It is a considered decision. That is the way it is going to go. Sorry chums, that is the way it is. Undesirable though these sales tax increases are, damaging though their impact may be--
It is recorded in Hansard that honourable senators were then interjecting. It is clear that they were honourable senators opposite. Senator Mason said:

Listen to this, senators, it is my bottom line. Those on the Labor side in particular should listen to this. Undesirable though the sales tax increases are , damaging though their impact might be, the consequences of the Senate meddling in or unilaterally rewriting a Budget seem to us too horrifying to contemplate.

Let there be no doubt that by rejecting these sales tax amendments that is precisely what they are proposing to do, rewrite the Budget, because, according to them, they are going to give some sort of tax rebate to those who would be buying the goods which are the subject of these sales tax amendments. Senator Macklin was good enough to tell the people of Queensland, and ultimately the people of Australia, what he thought in a letter which he wrote to the Courier- Mail in Brisbane and which was published on 2 September 1981. Senator Macklin said this:
The Australian Democrats Senators acted properly in refusing to join the Labor Party's attempt to defeat the Budget legislation on sales tax, even though under considerable pressure.
The widespread criticism with which the sales tax lifts were greeted put us in a position to gain much electoral popularity by heading them off.

The sales tax provisions have many disturbing effects-on the building industry, first home buyers, low-income families, and they would introduce an unwarranted new tax on information-but the legal advice we have received is that they are part of the Budget parcel. As such, no Senate has the right to reject them.

The Australian Democrats were elected under a promise never to use our power in the Senate to block Supply-and rightly so. Nobody should want a repetition of the events of November 1975. By referring part of the legislation back to the Lower House, we have steered away from this possibility and at the same time we have given voters an opportunity to register their disapproval.
They were opening themselves in this letter to the lobbyists, and apparently recognised and welcomed that. The letter continued:
By taking the stance it did last week Labor-also pledged not to block Supply- has abandoned all pretence of political principles.
That is what Labor did; it abandoned all pretence of political principles. I will skip a little of his letter; it is not really important for this matter. It continued:

Irrespective of the potential electoral backlash to the Democrats, we will not follow the Liberal and Labor parties in breaking election pledges. We could hardly claim to keep either of the old parties honest unless we are honest ourselves.

That is what the Democrats said. As I said, at first I was drawn to the conclusion that they were political opportunists of the worst kind in doing precisely what Senator Macklin said they would not do. But I have since come to realise that during the past five months they must have been subjected to an enormous amount of lobbying. During that same period I suffered very little lobbying. I probably had 20 letters over the whole five months. I have spoken with many of my colleagues. Very few of them have had any lobbying because the Liberal Party made its position clear. We said that these were Budget Bills and we intended to put them through. On the other hand, the Democrats said that they were open to argument, so they have been inundated with lobbying. They believe that somewhere along the line there is some political capital to be gained.

I do not know what the Democrats' principles are. I do not know whether there is anyone anywhere who can say what the members of that party stand for. If they are open to persuasion on any Bill and may change their minds about it, who can say what they stand for until such time as they vote? It seems to me that after they vote apparently they frequently change their minds. I think that some of them wish that they had not voted the way they did at a later stage. This party has no principles at all. It once said that it had a principle, and its members were chosen at the last election on the basis that they would never reject Supply. It is now perfectly clear that they have no principles because they are open to persuasion on any Bill, whether it is a money Bill or not.

Honourable senators have given examples to this chamber-Senator Missen last night gave an example-of the sorts of money Bills that the Democrats may reject. Last night Senator Siddons said that the decision which the Democrats made to reject the sales tax Bills was taken because they did not intend to increase a burden on the family, a burden on the housing industry and other burdens on the people of Australia. Therefore, they intend to reject the Bills. Where are their principles? They are open to persuasion for these reasons in relation to these Bills. What reasons will they accept in relation to a future money Bill? Clearly , the Democrats accept the proposition that they can reject any Bill which is presented to this chamber. Let me draw their attention to an editorial which was published in the Canberra Times last Saturday. The Canberra Times is not really known as being a newspaper which supports this Government. The editorial was headed 'Acrobatic Democrats'. It stated:

The decision by the Australian Democrats to oppose the sales-tax Bills in the Senate, repudiating their previous pledges to the Government and mocking their own pretensions to constitutional integrity, would be tragic if it were not farcical.
The editorial then discussed matters, which I will raise later during the second reading debate, about the legislation before the chamber. It continued:

In theory, Australia has an equitable and efficient taxation system based on progressive income taxation with not much indirect taxation. In practice, the system is neither fair nor efficient. Income tax has become pretty much a discretionary tax for people not dependent for their income on wages and salaries, and for those in receipt of large salaries.
The editorial gave some figures. It continued:

The figures are not up to the minute, but they give an idea of the magnitudes involved: a couple of years ago Labor's spokesman on economic affairs, Mr Willis , pointed out to Parliament that during 1977 and 1978 wage and salary incomes rose by 17 per cent and income tax on wage and salary incomes rose by 21 per cent. By contrast, non-wage and non-salary incomes rose by 37 per cent in the same period but income tax on them was down some 5 per cent.
They are interesting figures. The editorial continued:

Again, last year Professor Russell Mathews, of the ANU, pointed out that wage and salary-earners were paying two-thirds of income tax 15 years ago but were now paying four-fifths of it; that if non-wage and non-salary-earners were paying the proportion of income tax they paid 15 years ago they would be paying $3,000m more. The extent of avoidance and evasion implied by those numbers simply is outrageous.

I have been a very strong opponent in this chamber of avoidance and evasion but that is not the subject of this debate. There is a problem because the income earner who does not come under the pay-as-you-earn system in Australia is paying such income tax as he wishes to pay. We must raise revenue from those people. That is what the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and this Government have been saying repeatedly. We must broaden our base of revenue. To suggest that this will impose a burden on low income earners quite frankly fails to understand what sales tax is all about. It is not a regressive tax because there is no sales tax on food, rent, power and rates. It is clear from statistics which have been taken out around the nation that these are the major items on which low income earners spend the vast bulk of their incomes-purely and simply on living. They spend their money on food, rent, power and rates. There is no sales tax on those items. They are the basic necessities. Sales tax comes in on the luxury items. Let us look at them. People can buy clothes. There is some sales tax on clothes. But the lower income earners pay sales tax on lower purchase prices because they do not buy such expensive clothes. They can buy $30 or $40 dresses and pay much lower sales tax than would be paid by someone who wanted to buy a $300 or $400 dress. It is ridiculous for the Opposition to talk about the terrible burden on low income earners. The lowest income earners of all are the pensioners. Let there be not the slightest doubt that, as a result of this increase in sales tax , the consumer price index will increase. As a result of the increase in the CPI pensions will increase and pensioners will recover--

TALK.START.PARA: —Six months later.
—Senator Ray said: 'Six months later'. He openly acknowledges that the pensioners will recover all the money that they will lose as a result of sales tax.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard one of the most extraordinary speeches in the Senate for a long time. It was easily the most negative speech that I have heard in either House for a number of years. There was absolutely nothing positive in it about the Sales Tax Amendment Bills. I hope the Australian Labor Party does not get upset that Senator Lewis denigrated it for only 10 minutes of his speech when he denigrated the Australian Democrats for 15 minutes and spent the remaining five minutes saying that sales tax is not a tax on the basic necessities of life, that clothing and footwear are not basic necessities. People can, in fact, go around barefoot. There is no law against anyone doing that. I do not know the extent to which people can go around naked. I think there are some laws about that. Senator Lewis and his ilk have a thing about the naked form, male or female. I imagine that they would be very upset if people walked around without clothing. How he can deduce that clothing is not a basic necessity of life continues to confound me.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me be brief in dealing with Senator Lewis. The greatest crimes of the Australian Democrats seems to be threefold. Firstly, we listen to people. What a dreadful thing it is for a political party to do, to expose itself to lobbyists! Senator Lewis seems to have some thing about lobbyists and about people who choose to make representations to political parties. I have said time and again- during my time in the Liberal Party-that there are not enough lobbyists in Australia. There is too much apathy. The more that housewives, single parent groups, pensioners and trade unions lobby members of parliament the better democracy will be served. Senator Lewis accuses us of being open to lobbyists. The second crime, flowing from that, is that we are available to have our minds changed. I say to Senator Lewis-this will be entirely foreign to him-that I am very proud when I sit in this chamber and have my mind changed either by the lobbyists whom he despises or by the logic of debate from one side or the other. I say, quite unashamedly, that on several occasions I have had my mind changed on issues by the force of argument in this chamber. In fact, I had my mind changed today on a matter that will arise tomorrow. Senator Evans, a man for whom I have enormous admiration, changed my mind on the deportation of a certain person. I had an idea about it but I was persuaded to change my mind by the logic and the compassion that Senator Evans put to me.

I think that any member of parliament who has the arrogance to say that nothing that is said in this chamber will change his mind-that is exactly what Senator Lewis said-is flying against the whole force and thrust of the Westminster system of government. Does he not know what the meaning of 'parliament' is? The derivation of the word 'parliament' involves speaking, listening and being persuaded. Senator Lewis is notorious as one of the 12 Liberals on the opposite side of the House who will do without question anything that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) instructs him to do. His name is always mentioned in relation to that. Thirdly, he says that we are saving ordinary people a decent tax. He opened his remarks by describing this tax as a decent tax. The kind of logic that forces that adjective into his description of this tax astonishes me. I confess to Senator Lewis that we have been inundated with representations from all over Australia, from all sections of the community, about this iniquitous sales tax on the necessities of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! They are not on the necessities of life. Why is a book a necessity of life?

—I acknowledge Senator Lewis's interjection only for the purpose of having it recorded in Hansard. His inanity exposes him for what he is. One phrase of Senator Lewis's speech which I did understand completely was when he said that he has not been inundated by any representations. He said he has not received any letters at all on this sales tax on the necessities of life. There is a perfect reason why Senator Lewis has had no letters. One of the best kept secrets in Victoria is that Senator Austin Lewis is a senator for that State. That is the simple reason why he has not had any representations. Senator Lewis should come to my office so that I can show him a few files. Maybe he could read a couple of my letters. I will share a few with him. I have had more representations on this issue than on any other issue since I became a member of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating nine sales tax Bills, most of which place a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on what the Democrats describe as the basic necessities of life. This is the first time that a tax is to be levied on footwear, clothing and on the rest of the items that we mentioned. Most of the items covered are essential goods which no family can escape buying, notwithstanding Senator Lewis. I refer to items such as clothing, footwear and food wrappings. Senator Lewis mentioned that food will not be taxed. Has he been to a supermarket recently and noted the number of food items that are not wrapped? I am sure that Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen will agree with me in a flash that an unnecessary and undesirable trend in our shopping is that everything that we buy is wrapped in foil or whatever. These Bills are the thin edge of the wedge in taxing food because they will tax food wrappings. They will tax magazines and newspapers. Apart from those items being necessities of life, placing a tax on magazines and newspapers for the first time philosophically is a dangerous precedent because it is placing a tax on knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I understand Senator Walter's reluctance to read books. I assure her that a great number of other Australians, particularly children, read books from which they learn about life and the world. The concept of placing a tax on learning is abhorrent to a great number of people.

SPEECH.PARA: If these Bills pass the Senate they will bring in $53m to the Government in the rest of the financial year. I got that figure from the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. However, covered in the Bills are a number of items which the Democrats describe as non-essential items such as building materials for commercial enterprises. There are some forms of drapery which, I agree with Senator Lewis, are not essentials of life. Other materials covered include cleaning materials, machinery for the repair of cars and the like. The tax on these items would account for something like $12m out of $53m of lost revenue. The Democrats, and I am reasonably sure the Australian Labor Party, would be prepared to pass in minutes legislation imposing a new sales tax on those non-essential items. If the Government is sincere in its lament that the refusal of the Senate to pass these Bills is exacerbating its deficit blowout, it has staring it in the face $12m that could be collected from a sales tax on these items. It could pick up $12m in this way. I say that in the presence of the Minister for Finance.

If the Government wants $12m to help its Budget it could begin collecting these taxes by introducing new legislation tomorrow. The Senate's rejection of these sales tax Bills on the necessities of life involves less than 0.2 per cent of the total income in the Budget.

I support Mr Eric Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association. He said that $53m, the subject of these Bills, is petty cash in the total context of a Budget of $40 billion. It is sheer humbug to say that it is anything different. I mention these figures because in latter days Mr Fraser and Mr Howard have led and orchestrated an exercise which can be described, even with prevailing charity, only as a tactic of deceit.

The Liberal-National Country Party Coalition partners, whose one of few claims to fame is that they are good managers of the economy, have suddenly found out that they have a disaster on their hands with the current Budget. We have heard Mr Fraser and Liberals such as Senator Lewis who say: 'You don't have to like us . We are Liberals. Yes, we are conservative. No, we don't care to much about the environment. Yes, we will sell uranium. Yes, we do all those nasty things. But we are good economic managers'. That is always used as the one excuse as to why people should vote for them. Their Budget has palpably failed to estimate receipts and expenditure, one of the first requirements, I would have thought, of a Budget. It has fallen miserably short of stemming inflation, reducing unemployment or halting interest rates for home builders. They have done something even worse. They clearly led the electorate to believe that if the tax base was broadened by the imposition of additional taxes, such as a sales tax, reductions in income tax could be expected. I challenge anyone on the Government side to deny that that was the expectation the Government raised in peoples' minds if the Senate agreed to the increase in sales taxes.

All that stategy I have outlined is now in tatters with the Government's estimates of expendiure and income in catastrophic disarray and hopes of tax cuts dissipated. The Government's Budget estimates are over $1,000m astray. But as late as yesterday Mr Howard was claiming: 'It is not our fault. We are good managers. It is the fault of those beastly strikers in Bass Strait and those nasty Democrats'. I know figures are hard to absorb so I will present just a few . The Budget esimates an income of about $40 billion. The action of the Democrats and the Labor Party will deprive the Government of about $53m this financial year. I leave it to the common sense of Australians to conclude whether Mr Howard and Mr Fraser are telling the truth or telling lies when they say that we are responsible for the deficit which is now running at over $1,000m . If one wanted to use stronger language one could well say--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are taking over the economic management.

—I ask Senator Missen, an honourable man, to listen. Any man or woman who blames a political party such as the Democrats or the Labor Party for being responsible for causing a deficit of over $1,000m when, by his or her own admission, the actions of those political parties will deny the Budget only $53m , is telling a conscious, deliberate and calculated lie. But the Treasurer and Mr Fraser, together with the grand parade of non entities which the Government trotted out last night and tonight in the Senate debate, have tried to add more mischief to that untruth. They have stated that the action of the Democrats will now make it impossible to grant income tax cuts. This has been said by Mr Fraser several times. It has been said by Mr Howard many times, and at least once in my company on a television interview, and of course repeated by the speakers in this debate.
—You are misquoting him.

—Senator Missen, I will quote him. The truth of this statement can best be judged from the following extract. I have the tape of the interview in my office for Senator Missen to listen to. It is of an interview with Mr Howard and myself on Nationwide on Tuesday 16 February last. Mr Howard had strongly implied that the Government could now not give income tax cuts because of the Democrats' decision to block sales tax Bills. Richard Carleton then immediately asked:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Democrats were again to change their mind on this issue and they pass the legislation, could we then have the tax cuts that for so long it has been implied are coming.
What do honourable senators think Mr Howard answered to that? There was an opportunity. He just said he would give the tax cuts if we passed the Bills. He said:
We would have a greater capacity to give them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit difficult to understand. You would have to be a fool of a lawyer.
—Senator Lewis, it would be necessary to be a lawyer to understand the trickery of answers like this. Senator Lewis being a lawyer would better know that than most of us.
—He is only a bush lawyer.
—Yes, with reference to Senator Evans, he is only a bush lawyer.

—I am very proud of it too, Senator. I can assure you that I am very proud of it. Let there be no doubt about that. I am only a bush lawyer. I wouldn't want to be an academic like that man over there, that's for sure.
—A Victorian bush lawyer.
—Order!
—Mr President, I wonder whether you can restrain Senator Lewis from becoming unduly excited.
—I call the Senate to order.
—Richard Carleton then said 'but' trying to pin Mr Howard down. Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have chosen my words on personal tax cuts carefully all the way along--

I rest the case there. This charge would be amusing if it were not being made by the Treasurer of this country. I refer to the charge that if it were not for the Democrats' action income tax cuts would be possible. The Treasurer by his own admission stated that the Democrats have saved people $53m of sales tax this year. Let us assume that we pass the Bills tonight or tomorrow night and that we can believe Mr Howard that after passing the bills the $53m extra would be given straight away in income tax cuts. Is the Senate aware of how much per person that would represent in income tax cuts? I have divided the number of taxpayers, roughly six million, into $53m. That would result in a tax cut of 17c per taxpayer per week. That shows the total absurdity and the total deceit of Government members who say that the $53m we are denying tonight is precluding the Government's giving tax cuts. Surely Mr Fraser or Mr Howard do not expect people to believe this. Although these Bills apply a tax of only 2 1/2 per cent to basic essentials, I know what governments do. People listening to this debate know what governments of any complexion do. Once this legislation this year applies a tax of 2 1/2 per cent to the necessities of life next year by the simple stroke of a pen the rate could go up to 7 1/2, 10 per cent or 12 per cent , and so away it goes. We believe it is just another addition to the long list of increased hardships imposed upon the Australian family. I will instance just the last 12 months. These figures were taken out for me today. I say that I find them shocking even though I am a politician and live with these things daily. The following are the increase in costs for the average Australian family for the last 12 months. I am sure my friend, Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen, who is listening attentively to this debate and who cares desperately for the Australian family, will be fascinated to hear what I am about to say.

In the last 12 months health insurance has increased by $7 a week. As a result of the sales tax that we have already passed in this Budget another $2.20 a week has been added. According to Mr Risstrom another $18.20 a week is added to the price of petrol because of the reneging on tax indexation. There have been two increases. Someone who drives a car about 400 kilometres a week pays 60c a week extra. Taking an increase in mortgage interest rates of only one per cent on a loan of $30,000 and extra $6 a week is added. The average family is now paying $ 34 a week more than it was 12 months ago for those sorts of things. Yet this Government and people such as Senator Lewis want to add to that burden and put another 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on the necessities of life. Of course, that list does not include price increases on food, clothing, electricity, postage and telephones. The rate of inflation is again 10 per cent and unemployment is 6 .4 per cent. The number of new jobs created in the economy has been halved from 160,000 to 80,000 this year. Does anyone who is listening believe that wages and salaries have increased by equal amounts? Does any Government senator allege that wages and salaries have increased more than the increases I have just read out? Yet there is astonishment amongst Government senators when there are industrial stoppages, when trade union militants can appeal to the trade unionists to strike. They wonder why it is and conclude that it can only be communist influence. Mr Risstrom says:
For the majority of Australians their wages have increased 88 per cent in the last six years. During the same period taxes and charges for health care have increased by a staggering 240 per cent.

I repeat that in the last six years wages have increased 88 per cent and taxes and health care charges have increased a staggering 240 per cent. Mr Fraser and Mr Howard blame the Democrats for preventing tax cuts because we have saved families $53m this financial year. Yet the Democrats, together with the Labor Party, have already given the Government ample room to grant income tax cuts if it wishes. We have already given the Government approximately $1 billion more in this Budget in the form of further sales taxes. Together with the gains from reneging on tax indexation, this should give the Government room to manoeuvre. Notwithstanding this record by the Government of punishing changes in the economic and social circumstances of average Australians-put aside for a moment the proven deceit of the Government's Ministers as to the reasons for their mismanagement-the Democrats are the first to admit that conflicting principles are at stake in their actions to block the sales tax Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hoping you would get on to principles.

—I will have a word to say about Senator Missen's principles in a moment. I advise him not to be recorded too much in Hansard tonight because my speech will be circulated far and wide to those people who believe in Senator Missen's so-called principles on blocking Supply. Our action in no way offends the pledge taken by Democrat senators before the last election 'not to block Supply or interfere with money Bills in a manner which would prevent the majority party from governing' or which 'might bring down the Government'. The astonishing thing is that Senator Walters in a question the other day and Senator Lewis tonight showed that they do not know the difference between a Supply Bill and a money Bill. A Supply Bill is a Bill which spends money; it is an Appropriation Bill. It is the kind of Bill that Senator Missen voted against in 1975, although he said that he did not. I will explain that in a moment. A Supply Bill enables money to be spent. A money Bill gathers money. There is a vast difference between the two and I hope that one day Senator Walters might learn that. These are money Bills and nobody is seriously suggesting that the denial of $53m out of $40 billion in a government's Budget could bring a government down. Is anyone suggesting that? However I frankly say that the Democrats would have preferred and would still prefer these Bills to be amended in the proper place, the House of Representatives. On that I agree with my friend Senator Missen. They should have been amended in the House of Representatives. I am worried-I have said that I have been worried-that the Senate is taking action to amend a Budget. I have said it is a precedent which I do not relish and I will say it again.
—Do you feel con- science-stricken?

—Yes, I do. That is an experience which could not be enjoyed by several honourable senators who interject. With their inanities and arrogance, consciences are absent. Therefore it would be impossible for them to ever suffer any twinges of conscience. I briefly refer to Senator Missen. Last night he made a holier-than-thou speech. I do not care what he calls me outside or inside the chamber.
—Nothing personal.

—I do not care whether the honourable senator gets personal. If he ever likens us to the Democratic Labor Party I will sue him for every cent that he has. I think that in what he said he was hitting below the belt. Let me refer to Senator Missen's principles. On 23 September last year he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a view which I held in 1975, which I hold now and which I will continue to hold. I hold the view that it is not for this chamber to alter the Budget Bills of the Government.

That is recorded in Hansard page 943. I turn to page 1241 of Hansard on 16 October 1975. The Senate was not dealing then with a small money Bill such as these Bills. Before it was the whole damned Appropriation Bill (No. 1) introduced by a Labor Government. Senator Missen was in Opposition. Senator Cotton, a Government senator, moved that the Bill be not further proceeded with. I can now look at the division, and who do we see voting aye? Surely we would not expect to find Senator Missen's name there, but there it is. Yet this man comes into this chamber and talks about principles on a money Bill when he voted against Supply in 1975. Now he has the effrontery to tell us that we are breaking some principle by voting against Bills involving $53m.

I accept the criticism levelled at me and the Democrats by editorials in newspapers that the Senate should not amend Budgets. I am deeply concerned at the implications of the 1981 Budget for future Budgets. But we believe that in these circumstances and in regard to these Bills people are not too keenly interested in esoteric and/or erudite arguments about constitutional propriety. The fact is that they have been savaged by a government for too long and want the Senate to take action.

Another major matter of the principle that we all ought to have regard to is that politicians should be responsive to the people in their electorates. That is one of the basic principles in a democratic society. I pay brief tribute to Mr Goodluck in the House of Representatives for at least paying homage to that principle. I believe that the intentions and actions of the Government are quite obscene. It now has the capacity to grant income tax cuts, but the intention clearly is to build up a secret kitty from which immediate tax and pension sweeteners can be extracted quickly in case of a politically opportune early election. If the Government wants to call an early election that is its business . But it has no right to play around with the people's money and store it up for its own sordid political purposes. That is why the Democrats will again keep this Government honest when it tries to validate the great petrol rip-off. The Government can try to bring in its petrol rip-off Bill and see how it goes. Mr Fraser promised categorically in Launceston three days before the last election that increased revenue from world import parity petrol pricing would be returned to the people as a first priority. That is another promise on which the Government has openly, blatantly and arrogantly welshed.

I know that these Bills have been a contentious matter. I ask Government senators to realise that in opposing them every one of the five Democrats has put his or her future on the line. We have put the future of the party on the line. We are prepared to do that, cop the flak and cop the lies that are told about us. If the Liberal Party wants to do that we have given the ground to accommodate it.
