SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The Bills that I now reintroduce into the Senate will impose sales tax of 2.5 per cent on a range of goods that are at present exempt from the tax. The measures represent the last of three groups of sales tax changes proposed as part of the 1981-82 Budget. The other two-an increase of 2.5 percentage points in sales tax rates and the correction of a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in sales tax classifications-are now law, operative on and after 19 August 1981.

I have previously drawn attention to the clear advantage that lies in effecting some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes. I spoke then about the potential that such a change generates for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit. The prospect of doing that depends very much on a broadening of the indirect tax base. In particular, the measures in these Bills must be brought into effect. One simply cannot discard measures designed to raise some $300m a year without jeopardising the capacity to accommodate other desirable measures in the Budget.

Despite some things which have been said against these Bills, the Government, after full consideration, is of the view that there is a clear balance of advantage in proceeding with them, and I therefore resubmit them for passage.

As honourable senators know, it is for constitutional reasons established practice to enact nine separate Acts when imposing sales tax. Constitutional consideratons also lead to these Bills being in exactly the same form as the Bills of the same title that failed to be passed by the Senate last year. The delays in their passage means that it will not be practicable to adhere to the planned commencement date of 1 January 1982 and, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has already indicated, a new operative date of 29 March 1982 has been set. It is the Government's intention that, as soon as these Bills have been passed by both Houses, a further Bill will be introduced to change from 1 January 1982 to 29 March 1982 the date on which these Bills will come into operation.

The approach in each of the nine Bills now before the Senate is to impose tax of 2.5 per cent on goods that are identified by reference to items in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, and which at present exempt the goods from tax. The technical effect of the Bills will be to levy the tax on goods that are at present exempted by items 51, 53, 54, 58, 60, 82 to 90F inclusive, 96, 105, 107, 113F, 120 and 120A in the First Schedule.

The broad classes of goods concerned are books, magazines and newspapers, building materials, packaging and wrapping materials, hand tools, clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester goods, motion picture films, servicing equipment and construction equipment. I emphasise that goods falling within any of these categories will still be exempt from sales tax if they are sold in circumstances in which an overriding exemption in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act applies. By way of example, where a school entitled to exemption under item 63A purchases books for the school's use, the books will remain exempt from tax. Similarly, where a manufacturer purchases hand tools for use as 'aids to manufacture', as defined, the tools will remain exempt under the 'aids to manufacture' head of exemption.

An explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the Bills is being made available to honourable senators and as this sets out more fully the goods affected by these measures, I think that I do not need to provide further detail at this stage. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at some $330m in a full year. The original estimate of the increase in revenue in the current year from those proposals was $132m. The delay in implementation means that only some $53m can be collected in the current year, a shortfall of $79m from that projected in the Budget Papers.

As I indicated earlier, the present Bills complete the legislative framework for the sales tax changes announced in the Budget, and it is desirable that they soon become law. It is now some six months since these proposals were announced in the Budget Speech, and Bills in the same form as the present Bills were introduced into this place. I therefore trust that the Senate will now give these Bills a speedy passage. In that spirit, I commend the present Bills, Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982), to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981[No. 2] (1982) which are now before the Senate impose sales taxes on some 2 1/2 per cent on a variety of items including clothing, footwear, soft furnishings, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and other things. Effectively the Bills seek to tax all goods that are not currently subject to sales tax except for food, medicine and wine. These taxes will be paid by the consumer. They will be paid by the average Australian household and will bear more heavily on large families than small families, on married people rather than unmarried people and on the poor rather than the wealthy.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards these Bills is as before. We oppose them and will vote against them. However, on this occasion we are somewhat heartened by what appears to be the new-found support of the Australian Democrats and by the continued support of Senator Harradine who, from the beginning, has opposed these Bills on the grounds of social principle as he sees it.

This change of mind by the Australian Democrats is welcome. It has been flamboyant in a sense, agonising, even heroic in a classical sense. It reminds me very much of that character in a Stephen Leacock novel who jumps on his horse and gallops off in all directions. In a sense the same sort of thing has happened to the Australian Democrats on a number of occasions. But we are happy to have with us on this occasion this band of 'Latter Day Saints' who have been converted to the position which the Labor Party has held consistently for a very long time. This change of mind by the Australian Democrats has been explained as being an error of judgment. I remind them that in some circumstances errors of judgment in politics can be very costly. But I say this in a spirit of kindly criticism, if I can put it that way, rather than in anger.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Haines

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we can take that.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sentor BUTTON-Senator Haines, I want to indicate the nature of that criticism because I said that people suffer from errors of judgment. The Labor Party suffered from the Australian Democrats error of judgment. We did not make the error of judgment but we were told by people like Senator Haines on 9 September last year:

I take the opportunity to engage in some backchat with Senator Button because he insists that we change our minds daily . . . It is therefore of no credit to the ALP, although I am sure that its members are acting within their principles as they see them, that it is hell-bent on taking or manufacturing the first opportunity which presents itself to get even.
Senator Mason said a week later in a rhetorical question:

I ask my friends in the Labor Party: If we had gone along with them hand in hand down the short nasty path back to November 1975, how would they have liked it if we had started meddling with their first Budget? What sort of a world would that have created for this country?

The Labor Party has suffered at the hands of Senator Haines and Senator Mason from this error of judgment. We feel, more in sorrow than in anger, that perhaps there should have been a touch of humility towards the Australian Labor Party in some of the comments that have been made recently by Australian Democrat senators.

I repeat that the Labor Party has been consistent in its opposition to its Bills. Fundamentally, the opposition arises from a consistency of principle and honesty in government which the Liberal Party Government of Malcolm Fraser does not have. He is the first Prime Minister in the history of this country to be described in the Hansard record as 'a liar' and for that to be uncontradicted. In that environment how can the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Government of Ministers in this House who have sought to explain this legislation do anything else so long as they follow that leader? That is the political standard that has been set by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of this country. Of course, the Prime Minister is concerned to run this country as he would run Nareen. The accounts are kept in a well-thumbed old exercise book. The people of the country are treated like sheep or dumb animals by this Prime Minister, and he is assisted in the process of running that farm, as he sees it, by a couple of jackeroos from the National Country Party who crack the whip whenever it is required. That is the standard which this Government has imposed.

The Government had no mandate to introduce this sales tax legislation. It was sneaked in after the last election. Let me be more precise about that. There was no mention of sales tax before the last election. Four days after the last election, in October 1980, the Prime Minister was asked on television in Melbourne what he would do about the introduction of indirect taxes. Do honourable senators know what his answer was? It was: 'No comment'. This was four days after the election. It took him that long to decide to change his mind or to reveal what was in his mind about this issue. I think I am quite justified in saying it was sneaked in after the last election. Not only were these bills sneaked in contrary to the understanding which the Government had given the people of Australia prior to the last election, but also they represent a specific repudiation of a pledge by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 12 March 1981 following a so-called review of the taxation system by this Government. The review embraced the question of whether the indirect tax base should be broadened. Following that review, the Treasurer, Mr Howard-the man who combined with the Prime Minister to deceive the Premiers at the Premiers Conference last year-said to the Parliament that to extend indirect taxation would be inflationary and the Government would not do it. So the Opposition charges this Government with repudiation of specific pledges which it made to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the specific pledge?

—I will quote it to the honourable senator in a minute. He can just suffer in silence. The Opposition charges this Government with repudiation of a specific pledge. We regard that as an issue of good faith. The Government has said one thing and, as usual, has tried to do another. The Senate should not pass legislation for which the Government had no mandate and which it pledged it would not introduce. This point is made important by the Government's undertaking that if indirect taxes of the sort proposed in this legislation were introduced, they would be coupled with reductions in personal income taxes. The people of Australia are entitled to ask every Liberal member of this Parliament: 'Where are those cuts in personal taxes?' Last week the Treasurer announced that quite definitely there would be no decrease in income tax rates in the near future, certainly not before the Budget. What did the Treasurer say on 12 March 1981 after the so-called tax review was completed? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout its consideration of this issue, the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax .

First of all, the terminology is interesting: '. . . if a shift towards . . . indirect taxation were to occur'. The Treasurer is saying: 'It would not be our fault if that actually happened; it would just be something that happened by some strange process of osmosis'. The Treasurer went on to say that such a change would be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax.

Let us look at the Budget Papers of a few months later to see what happened in that regard. There was a 22 per cent tax increase for pay-as-you-earn taxpayers in Australia. According to the Budget Papers an additional $3 1/2 billion would be gleaned in personal income tax. The amount is more if we accept the figures of some of the outside commentators. That is what Mr Howard said and that is what was repudiated three months later and again by the introduction of this legislation. In the same document the Treasurer went on to say that the purpose of the taxation review was to do the following:

Assess the desirability of altering the mix or combination of taxes, to the extent possible, in the context of reducing the overall burden of taxation; it was not about an increase in the overall taxation burden.

There has been a shift from one area to another. Let us look at what has in fact happened. There have been no personal income tax cuts: There has been a greater burden on indirect taxation. If the issue is in fact one of broadening the tax base in Australia, let us have a debate about that issue in this Parliament. Honourable senators in this place, many of whom are ignorant about what has gone on in the Senate over the years, are now trying to shift the nature of the debate. Senator Hill made a fine and thoughtful speech last night about the desirability of spreading the tax burden. That is very idealistic but has nothing to do with what has happened under the Fraser Government. All these speeches remind me of that character in My Fair Lady who, oozing charm from every pore, oiled his way across the floor. That is the only thing that Government senators do not do: They do not cross the floor, but they oil their way out of the argument which they ought to face up to in this Parliament; that is, that concerning the credibility of the Government on this issue of taxation. That is the issue that Government senators have to face up to. There is a greater burden of indirect taxation and there are no promises of personal income tax cuts in the foreseeable future. The Government is, in fact, increasing the tax burden.

The issue, primarily, is one of credibility. It is about the honesty or otherwise of this Government. It is about the legitimacy of the Fraser Government, something over which there has been a dark cloud since 11 November 1975. I use the word 'legitimacy' and not the opposite when I talk about this Government in the Senate. It is a question of concern of the legitimate aspirations of the people of Australia to be able to rely on what a government says it will do. The people of Australia cannot do that with the Fraser Government.

Not content with this contradictory and deceitful position, the Government is bent on further misrepresentation of the issue. The Government's capacity to mislead has been well illustrated by its reaction to the Senate's rejection of these sales tax Bills. The Treasurer, with a straight face, says that rejection of the Bills by the Senate will make future tax cuts more difficult. That is bunkum in the context of the personal income tax take arising from the last Budget. Senator Chipp has dealt with that issue, and I do not want to go over it at any length. In saying that, Mr Howard makes no mention whatsoever of the fact that the rejection of the Bills will save taxpayers more than $50m this financial year. In a full year, sales tax would have taken about $330m out of the pockets of Australian taxpayers, the people whom Government senators say they are concerned about. These are the people the Government says it is concerned about. We are talking about mostly low and middle income earners when we talk about those on whom the imposition of this sales tax provision will have the real effect. The amount of $330m is nothing compared with the additional $5, 000m, for example, that the Government will gain next year from PAYE tax collections, based on the progress which is presently being made. To argue that the Government needs sales tax revenue which would result from the present Bills in order, at some unstated and future time, to offer personal income tax cuts is ridiculous, unless it is for the purpose which Senator Chipp touched on in his speech earlier tonight.

I want to talk about the Bills and the Budget strategy for a minute. The Government speaks of the refusal to pass these Bills as endangering its Budget strategy. Senator Lewis had a lot to say about that matter tonight. But the Government's Budget strategy is clearly in tatters, with or without these sales tax Bills. Current estimates of the Budget blowout reach as high as $1.4 billion . We are talking about $300m-odd in a full year. The country is being pushed by this Government into deeper and deeper recession and an alarming escalation of interest rates is threatening every Australian. When the relatively small amounts that will be raised by this Bill are put into their perspective we can see how calculatedly alarmist and misleading are the Government's claims about its Budget strategy. In short, the Government has consistently gone back on its pledges, has consistently misrepresented the situation and has misled the nation about both the effects of these sales tax increases and the so-called Budget strategy.

There are other aspects of the Bill which are repugnant. The Treasurer himself said in March 1981 that such a step would be inflationary. The Bills are regressive; the taxes fall more heavily on lower income earners. Public reaction is overwhelming against the Bills. People are right to be concerned that they will have to pay on average an extra $1.50 per week if these taxes are introduced. They are right to feel that the Government misled them over the sales tax issue. There are particular reasons for opposition to the tax on books and the necessity of life items which are dealt with by this legislation.

The Bills have also been discussed in the context of this first reading debate as an aspect of Supply. There has been a great deal of confusion in this place- deliberately calculated confusion, one suspects-as to the Labor Party's decision to reject the sales tax legislation, a decision which was made right from the start of this legislation being introduced. The decision is in no way one which endangers the Government. It does not endanger its Budget strategy, as I have tried to point out, and the Labor Party is not rejecting a Supply Bill or an Appropriation Bill. This is a measure designed to create new taxes. Over a number of years in the Senate the Labor Party has consistently opposed various revenue measures announced in respective Budgets. This case is no different from those on previous occasions and is classically in accord with what Government senators in opposition did to the Medibank levy, at great cost to this country, in 1974 and 1975. The then Opposition rejected it in the Senate. Did the Labor Party Government go away whinging like present Government senators have been about that rejection of a tax measure of this kind? What we had to do was establish Medibank without the levy. That is why we have had about six changes in it since under the Fraser Government. It was a stupid decision which the then Opposition made but we did not complain about it. It is a totally classic analogy with what is happening in connection with these sales tax Bills.

I think it is very important to distinguish the position of the Labor Party on this type of legislation from the position of the Liberal Party in opposition. I do not think we should forget these issues when we hear pious speeches on this question from honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. For the benefit of those senators who were not here at the time, I shall quote what Senator Withers said in April 1974. Honourable senators will recall that in three years of a Labor Government the then Opposition twice put it to the jump. How can a government govern when it is twice put to an election in three years by an Opposition which refuses it the right to govern, not an opposition which just rejects a particular aspect of its taxing legislation? What did Senator Withers, the then Leader of the Opposition, and later the Leader of the Government in the Senate until he was deposed by one of the Government's palace coups, have to say about this on 11 April, after the first time? He said:
We embarked on a course some 12 months ago-I am not trying to be provocative-to bring about a House of Representatives election. That has now been achieved.
Three months after the Labor Government got into office the Liberal Party embarked on a course to destroy it in this Senate chamber, as it did in 1974 and 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —You destroyed yourselves.

—That was a tactic which the Liberal Party adopted. Senator Walters should keep quiet for a moment. She will have an opportunity to speak later, no doubt. In those three years that was the course the Liberal Party adopted as a matter of policy, as stated by its leader. Liberal senators give us hypocritical talks in this place about knocking off a bit of tax legislation and chide or roast the Democrats about their error of judgment as if Liberal senators were people who could seriously talk in all intellectual honesty about anything like this. —I am asking Senator Walters to look at the document, not to bleat about the Curran scheme. It is only in the last two years--

SPEECH.PARA: I was referring to the question of Supply when I digressed. I think it is important, as we have said time and again, to distinguish between Supply and Appropriation Bills, the rejection of which would force a Government to an election-it is very hard to cop, but we will not do it-as happened in 1975, and Bills such as the present sales tax proposals. I have referred also to the Labor Party's attitude when in opposition. I have found the quotation from Professor Mathews which was temporarily eluding me. He said:
Indeed, if the same enthusiasm were to be shown by the Commonwealth for controlling revenue collections as for controlling Government expenditures, higher rates of taxation would be unnecessary.

It does not affect the life and continuance of the Fraser Government. As I said before that is a very hard thing to do. We would like to make the Government walk the plank as soon as possible, but we will not do that. We profoundly differ from the Government on a question of principle. We have, as I said, been quite consistent in our attitude to these Bills over a long period. We do not think they will make much difference to the so-called Budget strategy because the so-called Budget strategy no longer exists. These Bills are just peripheral to the Government's Budget strategy.

I want to make it quite clear, as we have tried to do on a number of occasions, that the proposals which we have consistently argued about relate very much to the whole question of the Government's mandate and its credibility as a government. If the Government wants to debate the question of broadening the tax base let us have a debate about it in Parliament. That is a very important issue on which I for one might not disagree with the Government as much as many of the government members think. If the issue is to be on the basis of lies and misrepresentation by this Government about what its intentions are, about misleading the Australian people, about promising one thing and doing another, we cannot meet the Government. We cannot even debate with it on that issue because the ground keeps changing all the time. One cannot have a debate in this Parliament about the important issues which were raised, for example, by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee about which very little has been done. It promised that when it took action it would do so in conjunction with income tax cuts. That promise again has been dishonoured. When we get some honourable statements of intention from this Government, if that is any longer possible, we can have a genuine debate in the Senate about honourable issues as this Parliament ought to do on the basis of a mutual understanding of differences of opinion and of philosophy. But we cannot do this with a shifty mob like this Fraser Government.

—Senator Lewis laughs. He ought to try to understand some of the history. He is one of the most pious and ignorant people in this chamber. That is the difficulty that he labours under persistently.
—He is also into nakedness.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that it is essential that at some stage during this debate somebody offers a compliment to honourable senators opposite for the consistent quality of the speeches that they have made on the sales tax Bills before us, particularly during the first reading debate. The speeches bore, as I am sure all honourable senators recognised, all the hallmarks of first rate political diatribes. They were full of hyperbole, purple passages and pseudo-tragic hand wringings and contained absolutely nothing of any merit whatsoever. Indeed, the deep, profound concern shown by Senators Missen and Watson for the purity of other senators in this chamber would have done the eunuchs in a sultan's harem proud. It was impossible, indeed, not to admire the terribly pretty picture the two of them made wringing their principled, honest little hands in alleged agony over what they saw as the rather misguided actions and lack of principles of some other senators. It will no doubt come as something of a shock to those senators and, I daresay, to Senator Lewis and to others that my colleagues and I can do without their little homilies, misguided and misbegotten as they are.

Since I am nothing if not a charitable soul and I work on the principle that one good turn deserves another I will give honourable senators a little reciprocal advice. In doing so I think I can do no better than to direct honourable senators attention to Senate Order No. 53 and in particular to that sentence of the President's prayer that seeks divine assistance 'to direct and prosper the work of Thy servants to the advancement of Thy Glory, and to the true welfare of the people of Australia'. A little thought on the meaning of that section of our daily Senate program could well prove beneficial to honourable senators.

A number of honourable senators tonight have raised the question of honesty in decision making and the behaviour of politicians generally. I agree with Senator Button that this is, in fact, the central issue of this debate. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said:

For reasons that were announced at the time, the Government decided earlier this year against a major restructuring of the tax system towards greater reliance on broadly based indirect taxes. That decision did not rule out later consideration of smaller adjustments within the present system.
It is clear that there is advantage in some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes to increase the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes, and particularly personal income tax-

One wonders how much longer one has to wait in this country for the present Government's idea of a potential situation to turn into an actual one. Clearly, as Senator Button has already pointed out, it was not the intention at all, although it appeared to be so from the Budget Speech, of this Government to trade off income tax cuts with increases in sales tax levies. The new system was wholly and solely a revenue raising tactic. Unfortunately, we, like a great many other people in this country, were foolish enough to believe the Treasurer. We believed that the Government really was only increasing indirect taxes and adding sales taxes to a series of hitherto exempt items so that it could expeditiously lower income taxes. Unfortunately, but probably not surprisingly to most people who have watched this Government in action over the last few years, the Government played the electorate for suckers. It was only the combined action of the Opposition parties in delaying the passage of the Bills that, in fact, allowed this con trick to become patently apparent to the people of Australia, people whose welfare, I remind the Senate, we daily pray to act for. Despite what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, says he believes, taxes on items which we have no choice but to buy are regressive. If the honourable senator cannot accept that fact I suggest that he ask any pensioner or any person on a fixed income. Even if the Government parties do not have the sense to see that element we do. Our party policy takes it into account ; it specifically excludes these items from any change in the tax base. It has done so since 1977. Unfortunately, again we all know that this Government has at best a very tenuous grasp of economic principles or, for that matter, any other sort of principle. To watch as we have done in this place in the past few months , the Government search frantically and with ever-increasing hysteria for somebody else to blame for the mess it has run this country into would be funny if it were not so tragic.

The mire into which Australia is sinking is not the fault of a Labor government that held power so briefly in the early 1970s. It is not the fault of world market influences. Since, after all, we are fairly isolated we have been able to look after ourselves up to date. It is not the fault of the Australian Democrats , who have in the interests of the community at large deprived the Government-if it wants to use that word-of a piffling $53m. It certainly is not the fault of the last of the so-called bad boys, the Bass Strait strikers. Presumably the Government has now run out of people to blame. I trust that in the very near future we can look forward to it doing what the rest of the country has been doing for some time-looking closely at Liberal Party policies and actions with a view to seeing where it went wrong in order to set about correcting the blunders it has made. To date, of course, it has not. It has the remarkable arrogance to think that the Liberal Party and any party foolish enough to go into coalition with it has some sort of divine right to rule and that people in the electorate can sit back and take whatever the Government chooses to hand out secure in the knowledge that the Government is doing whatever is best for them no matter how much it hurts. Some of us are getting heartily tired of being told by this Government that it knows what is best as we watch ourselves rushing further and further into the mire.

To date all that the Liberal Party Government policies seem to have done is to squeeze the ordinary Australian one way or another for every cent he or she is fortunate enough to be able to earn. It is anticipating legislation that will make sure that none of that income earned gets ferreted away in non-interest bearing cheque accounts just in case this deprives the Government of some revenue. It insists on making sure that taxes, taxes and more taxes are applied to the pay-as-you-earn employee whilst calmly letting the millionaire Liberal Party donating tax cheats get away with everything short of murder. The Liberal Party Cabinet is aided by its lily-livered back benchers who are prepared to do the sort of thing that Senator Missen so proudly does regularly-bleat mildly and then follow the party line. They are eunuchs-every one of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit rough! I didn't go that far!

—Well, I am afraid that although this Government and its lily- livered-if Senator Chipp prefers that as an epithet-back benchers may be prepared to abrogate their responsibility to the people of Australia, we are not . This Government has to learn-I think that over the last couple of weeks it has started to learn-that if it treats the Parliament and the Australian people with contempt it will have only itself to blame if the Parliament and the people react by rejecting its draconian and muddle-headed economic policies. The extent of the muddle-headedness of some of its policies was made very apparent as recently as this morning in an interview that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) gave to a reporter from the Australian Financial Review. I shall quote a couple of sentences from that interview. For honourable senators who are vitally interested in it, it starts on page 6 of this morning's Financial Review. Half- way through the interview the reporter said to the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Just before Christmas you and various senior ministers were saying that the budget was broadly on track.
That is quite the reverse, I might add, of what the Government has been saying in the last couple of weeks. It seems a remarkable turnabout for a little over a month. The reporter continued:
What has gone wrong?
Why wasn't the Budget more carefully monitored so that the contribution to the blow-out from Government spending could have been averted?
The answer that the Prime Minister gave to that question in the long run was to blame overspending in the departments and to say:
If a department is starting to over-spend on the sort of rate you would expect throughout the year, it needs to be hauled back right at the beginning of the year, or as soon as the trends emerge.
The reporter asked:
So the previous monitoring hasn't been efficient enough?
The Prime Minister responded:
Well, the habit of spending money just seems very hard to get people out of.

Undaunted by this the reporter pressed on and questioned the Prime Minister about the three-tiered tax scale which was introduced by this Government for reasons of simplicity and equity in 1976 and which appears to be no longer serving that purpose. The reporter asked:
Have you considered increasing the number of tax brackets as a means of ensuring that neither pensioners nor people on average weekly earnings are unfairly taxed?
The Prime Minister has such a forward-looking policy-he is so au fait with what is happening-that his answer was:
I cannot pre-empt what is going to be said about or done about taxation at some time in the future . . . It seems to me that it is very hard to get people to recognise reality in this area.
It seems to me that it is very hard to get the Prime Minister to recognise anything very much at all. The reporter said:
Nevertheless, when the three tiers were introduced, I think there was something like 90 per cent of people on the lower scale. That is no longer true.
The Prime Minister said:

I recognise the problem of maybe average weekly earning people going into the middle bracket, and the Government does recognise, the problem that has not yet arrived, of people on the pension coming close to the tax threshold.
I do not know how much closer he expects them to get without actualling arriving . He continued:
Those problems never would have arisen if Mr Hayden had not introduced taxes on pensions.
The reporter said:
You have not abolished them?
Mr Fraser responded:
No, we have not. There are some things that governments do that seem to just go on once they have been introduced.

I think that says just about everything about this Government's attitude to economic planning, to honesty, to principles and to caring about the welfare of the people of Australia. If after this sort of comment from the Prime Minister this Government really expects the Parliament and the people to sit mildly back as we are driven further and further into financial despair, I am afraid that it is very much mistaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating tonight the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax legislation. I am sure that most people in Australia will be aware that these Bills have been debated in this chamber now at least three times. Because time is so short, I will not go into the detail of the reasoning behind the Government's introduction of this broader based tax. Suffice it to say that it is acknowledged world-wide that an emphasis on personal tax makes it much easier to indulge in tax avoidance and tax evasion than does an emphasis on any other form of tax. Enacting the Bills before us would certainly be one way of making it more difficult for people to indulge in these abuses. All the emotive words spoken in this chamber by Senator Chipp about children's clothing, all the lobbying by the media and the use of emotive words about a tax on knowledge and papers have been part of an attempt to exaggerate that 2 1/2 per cent beyond all reason.

SPEECH.PARA: What is 2 1/2 per cent on the price of a pair of shoes, for instance? Let us look at some prices. Let us say that a pair of shoes costs $30. What is the 2 1/ 2 per cent sales tax on that amount? It is 75c. on $60 it is $1.50 and on $100 it is $2.50. What will be the extra cost of a newspaper as a result of this supposed tax on knowledge? It is less than half a cent. Yet all major newspapers put their prices up by 5c just a short time ago. The tax on knowledge is less than half a cent on the price of a daily newspaper. However, it is quite a considerable amount to the Government. A total year's revenue from the tax is $ 330m. We have not heard from many of the Premiers on this subject. We have to remember that part of this revenue, part of the $330m, goes directly to the States.

It will be interesting to hear, when the Premiers wake up to what the Democrats and the Labor Party have denied them, what the Premiers will be saying to their senators in this place. The argument that the denying of $330m in revenue to the Federal Government will prevent the Federal Government giving tax cuts has been pooh-poohed in this place. I agree; it probably will not. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) probably will still be able to manage some tax cuts. But it would be a very foolish person who would say that the Government, with $330m less in its kitty, can now give as many tax cuts or so great an amount of tax cuts as it would have been able to do had the sales tax legislation gone through. I have no problem with the Constitution regarding the Labor Party's refusal to pass the Bills. It has that constitutional right. —Mr Hayden said that very clearly, but now he has changed his mind and has said that it is quite constitutional; and the Labor Party has said here tonight that it is constitutional. The Democrats told us that they did not agree with the blocking of money Bills. They told us they believed it would be detrimental to people. Yet at that stage they said: 'Take away some of the financial policies of a government and you remove its mandate. That is the opinion which is thoroughly respectable and which we feel we must stay with.' Later Senator Mason said:

We believe that if either of the two major parties is elected to government it has a certain mandate and a right to exercise it. A small party should not meddle or allow itself to be persuaded by somebody else to meddle with money Bills and legislation of that nature.
He did not refer to Supply Bills. His statement related to money Bills. He continued:

Headlines! Terrific story.
Senator Ryan interjected:
You would hate that.

Well, we were tempted for about 17 seconds, Senator, to be quite honest with you.

I have quoted the words of Senator Mason and Senator Haines on the way they interpreted the statutory declarations at the time of signing them to apply not only to Supply Bills but also to money Bills. TALK.START.PARA: —Also associated with the question of taxation and wage demands are numerous claims peddled recently by the Government to the effect that increases in real disposable household income are the criterion of economic performance and government competence. It is claimed by the Government that real disposable household incomes increased substantially in 1980-81 and therefore that these increases should have moderated claims both for wage increases and tax deductions. The figures cited by the Government have never allowed for the increase in the number of households, which erodes almost half the recorded increase, changes in interest rates which, of course, have been upwards and changes in health insurance premiums. As real disposable household income is defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics increases in those factors are not reflected.

SPEECH.PARA: More important than the inadequate definitions and qualifications which the Government has supplied for the figures it has circulated is the fact that the most recent available statistics-those for the September quarter of 1981-show that, far from increasing, real disposable household income is lower than it was in the same quarter of 1980. In fact, adjusted for or converted to September 1981 value dollars the average disposable income per household in the September quarter of 1980 was $5,023. It has fallen in the September quarter of 1981 to $4 ,994. Certainly that is not a large fall but it is still a decline and not an increase as the Government would have us believe. Of course in those figures I have cited no allowance is made for increases in interest rates or health insurance premiums which have taken place since the September quarter of 1980.

If we take a longer term view of changes in disposable household income we find that under the Labor Government-which this Government would normally have us believe was catastrophic in the area of economic management-real disposable household income increased by 23 1/2 per cent. That was an average of almost 8 per cent a year for the three years that Labor was in government. In the six succeeding years it has increased by an aggregate of 11.2 per cent which is somewhat less than 2 per cent a year. Indeed in two of those financial years since the Fraser Government has been in office changes in real disposable household income have been negative. In only one of those years has real disposable household income increased by as much as or more than it did in the year with the lowest increase under the Labor Government. So much for household income and Pollard's false assertions on relative taxation levels.

The Labor Party, as Senator Button has already stated, will oppose these Bills at the second reading stage and, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats , will defeat them. I understand that at least one other senator will vote against them. We oppose the whole package of sales tax Bills originally introduced on Budget night in August of last year. We have opposed them at all stages and at all times. I will summarise very briefly the history and the reasons for having done so. We oppose these Bills because they are regressive and because the proportion of income they will rip off low income groups will be higher than the proportion of income they will rip off high income groups. They are inflationary and they will intensify the economic recession which was already in the pipeline when the Bills were originally introduced in August of last year and which has intensified since. They are unjust, inflationary and unnecessary.

That applies to all the Bills that were introduced with the Budget. They came in three packages. The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9), increased by 2 1/ 2 per cent almost all pre-existing rates of sales tax. That package, regrettably , was passed by the Government, assisted by the Democrats, last year. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill, which increased pre- existing sales tax on a number of items, imposed sales tax on some new items at rates of up to 27 1/2 per cent and reduced sales tax on a number of smaller items, also has been passed. The third group of Bills in the original package, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A), are those which are before the Senate tonight. They seek to impose a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on a wide range of previously untaxed goods.

The Bills which are before the Senate-the first two groups of Bills having been passed in spite of the Labor Party-were estimated to yield $330m in revenue in a full year and $132m in this financial year had they become operative on 1 January this year, as originally planned. If they were to be passed by the Senate tonight or tomorrow, which they will not be, I understand the estimate is that they would yield something like $60m in revenue this financial year if they were proclaimed when the Government planned to proclaim them. In a full year the three groups of Bills would have yielded an estimated $982m of which $330m is attributable to the Bills before the Senate now.

Last year the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) were thrown backwards and forwards on several occasions between the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Bills contain what the Australian Democrats have asserted to be, to use their words, the necessities of life. The Democrats have claimed and have probably believed that the taxes imposed by the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) are more regressive than are the sales taxes imposed by the other Bills which have already been passed. They are wrong in making that assumption. There is almost no difference between the degree of regressivity in the entire package as originally introduced with the Budget in August of last year and that in the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) which are the subject of debate now.

In round terms the regressivity works in this way: The Australian Bureau of Statistics, in its most recent survey of household expenditure, which regrettably was six years ago, has identified six strata of income. The lowest income stratum will pay twice as much, as a proportion of income, based on the expenditure pattern of 1975-76, as the highest income group. As a result of the increases in sales tax from the three different packages of Bills as a whole-the whole original $822m-the lowest income group will pay as a proportion of income twice as much tax as the highest income group. The four intervening groups will pay about the same amount and will fall about half-way between the lowest and highest income groups. In other words, as a proportion of income they will pay about 70 per cent or 75 per cent as much as the lowest income group.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detail the history of the Australian Democrats' reactions to this package of sales tax Bills through all its contradictions and contortions. However, it should be noted that their rationale for opposing what they call a tax on the necessities of life is based on a specious assumption that the so-called necessities of life impose taxation more regressive than do the entire three groups of Bills. It befits a Mickey Mouse party that it should make such an inaccurate assumption. I also note that the Democrats' repudiation last week of what was previously claimed to be a highly principled position befits a party which is led by somebody who discovered principles only when Malcolm Fraser sacked him from the Ministry in 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent arguments advanced by the Government in defence of these sales tax hikes are even more spurious than those advanced by the Democrats in support of their position and the multiple changes in that position. I will demolish the spurious Government's arguments. The first one is the claim that failure to pass these Bills and impose the taxes contained in them from 1 January has caused the deficit blowout. If the Bills had become operative on 1 January they would have yielded $130m or $132m this financial year. But the Budget deficit is blowing out by about $1.4 billion, a factor ten times as high as the loss of revenue from these Bills. At the most-at the very worst, from the Government's point of view-the rejection of these Bills will be responsible for about 10 per cent of that Budget deficit blowout. The second specious argument used by the Government is that a refusal to pass these Bills will preclude income tax cuts either later this financial year or next financial year. If income tax cuts were the inevitable consequence of sales tax increases, why was no income tax cut amendment Bill introduced or foreshadowed in August last year when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and everybody else in the Government expected these Bills to pass without difficulty?

That particular claim by the Government is a retrospective rationalisation of the abandonment of the Prime Minister's repeated promises to reduce personal income tax or even, indeed, to cease harvesting massive tax increases due to what economists call fiscal drag and what the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation. As for next financial year, in the context of possible changes in income tax collections, the rejection of these Bills will cost the revenue about $330m which is insignificant when compared with the $5.5 billion increase in personal taxation which the secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, Mr Risstrom, estimates will be yielded to the Government. That figure, in real terms, is about $2.5 billion, even after adjustment for the lower value of taxation revenue caused by increasing inflation. On Mr Risstrom's projections, even after we have adjusted for that, what Mr Fraser used to call the secret tax of inflation, and what he used to catigate piously as the secret tax of inflation, will increase the real revenue available to this Government from personal income tax by $2.5 billion or more.

The Government has the temerity to claim that the rejection of the sales tax Bills which would have yielded a paltry $330m, about 13 per cent of that total, has precluded changes in income tax in the next financial year. The Government claims that it cannot balance the Budget unless it receives the revenue that it planned to receive from these Bills. Leaving aside the fact that the Budget is already grossly unbalanced and that an unbalanced Budget may not be inappropriate for an economy sliding into deep recession, as the Australian economy currently is, the Government has in fact a wide variety of alternative sources of revenue.

Firstly, and most importantly, it could crack down on tax evasion which, according to Professor Mathews, results in the loss to revenue of $7 billion a year. I think that estimate is probably high but an estimate of the cost to revenue of $3 billion is highly credible. Senator Walters attempts to run away from this issue by saying: 'Your government did not stop tax evasion'. She actually said that our Labor Government did nothing to stop tax evasion, which is not true. There were at least eight specific amendments to the Taxation Act for that purpose passed in the three years of the Labor Government. She has some justification for castigating the Australian Labor Party for having been tardy in legislating against the Curran scheme, although I note that her Government was even more tardy; it took nearly one and a half years to do it. But, never mind whether the Labor Government was more reprehensible or more negligent in this area than the Fraser Government used to be, the important issue is what is going on right now.

What is going on right now is that at least $3 billion is being lost to revenue through tax evasion which would be stopped immediately by the credible threat of retrospective legislation. I say the credible threat because I do not believe it would be necessary to legislate, certainly not more than once, so long as the threat was believed. As I have said, $330m is an insignificant amount compared with what the Government chooses to forgo because it refuses to crack down on tax avoidance.

Secondly, but less important quantitatively, the Government could cut out some or most of the sixty-four tax concession which were the subject of questions on notice from my colleague Ralph Willis and which appear in the House of Representatives Hansard of 16 February. Two thirds of those 64 questions about concessions could not be or were not costed-a prime example, I presume, of responsible government in operation! The Government writes 40-odd concessions into the income tax legislation and it does not even know what the cost to revenue of those 40 concessions is, or if it does know it will not tell. The one -third that were costed in the replies to Ralph Willis's questions amounted to more than $1 billion a year cost to revenue on a full year basis. Most of those concessions were introduced by the Fraser Government usually without costing, or sometimes with a dishonest costing initially, and usually not only uncosted but also straight off the top of the Prime Ministerial head without paper, without written submissions to Cabinet and without prior departmental consultations.

The most notorious of these, of course-although it is not the most expensive it is the most notorious in context-is the film tax rort under which it is possible for the Government to pay $120 by way of forgone revenue for every $100 spent or invested in the production of a film. In other words, it might well be cheaper for the Government to foot the entire bill for film production than to subsidise it through the taxation system in this way. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) did not supply an answer to Ralph Willis on that one but earlier estimates which came from the Department of the Treasury show that this is likely to cost $20m this financial year. That idea was put to Cabinet straight off the top of the Prime Ministerial head upon which it had apparently been placed by some make-up assistant in a Sydney television studio. Again that is responsible government in operation! When John Stone found out about it he went beserk. He and the other boffins in the Treasury are currently trying to repair the haemorrhage of revenue caused by political stupidity and irresponsibility by defining production costs so tightly and I suppose even unrealistically or unfairly. They intend to stop the revenue haemorrhage in that way. That, of course, is an understandable reaction by responsible bureaucrats though it is no substitute and is no acceptable alternative to responsible and sensible government in the first place.

Most of the costed concessions-costed that is in the answer to Ralph Willis's question-are primary producers' concessions which incidentally directly benefit half the Federal Cabinet including the Prime Minister. Let me give a few of them . One is primary producers income tax averaging at a cost of $215m. John Stone, the Treasury's Secretary, publicly described this at the Agricultural Outlook Conference last year as a system which operates in this way: Heads the farmers win and tails all other taxpayers lose. The admitted cost is $215m. There is a valid case for tax averaging; there is no case for tax averaging as it has operated since the legislation was amended by this Government in 1978 as a result of yet another stupid and irresponsible Prime Ministerial promise given before the 1977 election. This is one of those very rare events in the life of this Government and this Prime Minister; it is one promise that was kept. He made a promise to himself and he kept it. He has hardly kept any promise he has ever made to anyone else. The primary production component of the investment allowance and the 20 per cent special depreciation allowance together are another $95m. I regret that time does not allow me to detail the rest of these outrageous rorts under which the Government could easily raise more revenue than it will be forced to forgo by the rejection of these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks now concern the current policy on what might be termed sportsmen's visas. Some South African nationals were included in the Sheffield Shield cricket competition, but I aim my remarks mainly at the football codes, at both the rugby codes and soccer. Let me say quite definitely that nobody quarrels about sporting bodies making their own domestic arrangements. Conversely, we do not object to any country, much less our own, controlling its intake of people. By and large, we have been fairly reasonable about the issue of sportsmen's visas. I know that there has been a fair flow of both soccer and rugby league players. In years gone by there was more money in the United Kingdom in the rugby league code, but now the situation is reversed. It is slightly different with soccer. Tony Henderson has a $60,000 contract to play in the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: My criticism relates specifically to the experience of a number of 18 and 20- year old Australian soccer players with rather modest ambitions to play a season in third of fourth division in either Britain or on the Continent at an age when their game structure is not finalised. They thought they might possibly come back and inject something into the Australian soccer scene. I suppose that, in contrast with New Zealand, we can say that we do not look to Sir Arthur George as the complete oracle on that code. Since last November a number of boys have sought to play in the European soccer season. I rang up both the East German and West German embassies and was told in a very bureaucratic way that those boys had to be registered on an aliens' list and all that sort of thing.

Again, I do not object to the British soccer players professional union wanting a limitation to be placed on players, but what I did resent was that union saying: 'Australians and New Zealanders will be restricted, but if you are a European Common Market national the ball game will be different'. The thrust of my argument tonight is to ask whether the Australian Government will respond to that and say: 'If you exercise that power we reserve the right to do the same'. I know you, Mr Deputy President, were involved on behalf of the Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia and the Musicians Union of Australia on a number of occasions when the British actors equity adopted a different attitude from ours. I know only too well the very notable role you played in conveying the views of people from Actors Equity to our Immigration Minister and that certain negotiations took place. I believe that this bias against Australia and New Zealand and in favour of European Economic Community countries should be noted. Perhaps the Minister could convey to me in the next few weeks the position of United Kingdom and Irish soccer players in particular who have come here on two-year contracts.

Some years ago-I think Senator Baume figured in this-arrangements were made for summit talks with the Soccer Federation and the then responsible Minister. I think it was Michael MacKellar. The general idea was this: There was what I call pyramiding of a contract. For example, a player was signed on for a two-year term. That two-year term equally applied to some rugby players. If their form was good enough, they were granted three periods of two years residence, thus accumulating six years of continued residence in Australia. Arrangements were generally made in relation to their acquiring permanent residence in Australia. That was at a time when the EEC ban on Australian and New Zealand players did not apply. Of course it can go further. I have a case on my records at the moment which I might apply to people here who follow the Australian Rules code. A number of Gaelic footballers from Ireland are here on certain Gaelic sports assignments. I do not know whether they will ultimately graduate into Australian Rules football. Probably people such as Senator Evans and Senator McLaren who know that code better than I do might comment. The fact is that Australia is fairly reasonable and lenient in this area. I feel the time is opportune, in view of the attitude of the British Home Office in relation to the football codes I referred to, to get an early response on what our attitude is. I admit that this pyramid system that I referred to occurred two or three years ago but I believe that having regard to all the circumstances it should be looked at rapidly.

I conclude on the note on which I began: Estimates Committee D was a very high- powered committee under the chairmanship of Senator Kilgariff. It was composed of Senator Sibraa and Senator McIntosh from our side and Senator Jessop and Senator Watson from the Government side. People have pious aspirations about the role of Estimates committees. Instead of holding up the Senate between 11 p.m. and 11.10 p.m.-I would like this message to be conveyed very forcibly to Senator Sir John Carrick by Senator Messner-if we lived up to the spirit of Estimates committees, and I am fortified in this by the thoughts of Senator Peter Rae, our Committee would have met during the first week of this parliamentary session. We could have had senior immigration officers before us and we could have got the truth of this one-way attitude on sportsmen's visas and possibly advised the British High Commissioner that we believe this bias in favour of the EEC should cease, or at least in turn we could take reprisals. I leave the matter at that.

The Hon. C. J. SUMNER: I seek leave to make a brief explanation before asking the Attorney-General a question about Orana Inc.

The Hon. C. J. SUMNER: I indicate that I am asking this question on behalf of the Hon. Dr Cornwell, shadow Minister for Health, who is absent on Parliamentary business and who is paired with the Hon. Mr Davis.

Orana Inc. was formed by a small group of parents of intellectually handicapped persons more than 30 years ago. At that time there were no educational facilities at all provided for these disadvantaged people in South Australia.

The original organisation became known as the Mentally Retarded Childrens Society. From the enthusiasm and dedication of the parents at that time and many who followed them, the organisation grew to a voluntary body which today provides 19 facilities-sheltered workshops, hostels and activity therapy centres -throughout South Australia. The activity therapy centres in particular were set up at the behest of the Federal Government. They were specifically to cater for those people with a low capacity to work in a sheltered workshop situation. Capital funding was provided on a Government subsidy and/or grant basis.

Recurrent funding was provided by widespread, well organised and enthusiastic voluntary fund-raising throughout the community. In addition, the Department of Social Security provided 50 per cent of approved staff salaries and some subsidies towards purchase and maintenance of equipment and premises. More than two-thirds of the running costs were met by voluntary fund-raising and small charges against the pensions of the intellectually handicapped people using the facilities. This was a very heavy burden for parents, many of whom were past middle age or on pensions. Nevertheless, it was accepted as a life-time commitment by them. After the financial squeeze imposed by the first Fraser Government in 1976, the organisation began to experience financial difficulties. It was by now a large and complex body providing a wide range of services.

In 1977 they applied for deficit funding to the State Government. This led to an inquiry which recommended changes in the administration to contain costs and streamline management. The inquiry found that administration costs had escalated alarmingly since 1974 while fund-raising, which by this time was being organised by so-called professionals, had declined markedly. Government officers concluded that, if the board of directors and the Executive Director, Mr Jim McLachlan, addressed themselves to these problems, financial viability could be restored. In other words, Mr McLachlan and his board were told to put their house in order . Despite these recommendations no effective changes were made at the time and the financial affairs of the society continued to deteriorate.

By 1978 Compton Associates Pty Ltd were engaged by management supposedly to find ways out of what was then a crisis situation. Unfortunately, implementation of the recommendations of the Compton Inquiry led from crisis to disaster. For the first time in almost 30 years parents were excluded from an effective voice or voting power on the new board of directors. Furthermore, the new board adopted the remarkable and reprehensible stance that it was no longer responsible to the members of the society, the vast majority of whom were concerned parents. Communication ceased and policies were promulgated without any consultation with the membership. All former methods of voluntary community fund-raising which had been so successful over the years were suspended and replaced with a so-called planned giving programme. The board demanded that parents must contribute regardless of their age or financial situation.
With regard to this enormous imposition Mr McLachlan said in a report to the board in August 1981:
Anyone who does not respond to the request for payment or arrangement for payment should be handed over to a debt collection agency and ruthlessly pursued for the money.

He further recommended that any money or assets inherited by the handicapped persons be compulsorily assigned to the society. In the meantime, because of the continuing deterioration in the organisation's finances, fees charged for services at the A.T.C.s were raised by 100 per cent to $20 per week. This was taken from the meagre invalid pensions of the handicapped persons.

An examination of the published audited financial statement for 1980-81 showed a very serious financial position and rapidly escalating operating losses. Without a very dubious revaluation of assets, accumulated funds would have been wiped out. There are numerous examples of gross financial mismanagement. When a lottery organised in 1979 to raise funds by raffling a 22ft Boomaroo yacht failed, ticket moneys were said to be refunded. The yacht, valued at approximately $12 000, was sold to a person who allegedly declared himself bankrupt before financial settlement. The yacht has since disappeared.

Thousands of dollars have been misappropriated in the Riverland. In one case partial resolution has been accepted and police investigations dropped at the instigation of Mr Jim McLachan. Allegations of further misappropriations have been very poorly investigated. In September many parents approached me for assistance. At the same time the deplorable conduct of the executive director, Jim McLachlan, and the board were reported to the Attorney-General, Mr Griffin, and the S.A. Health Commission. At this stage parents were desperate to have the affairs of Orana Inc. put in order to ensure the continuing availability of services to their sons and daughters. At that time they believed this could be achieved by amending the constitution in conjunction with a private Government- sponsored inquiry. They were very anxious to protect the former excellent reputation and public standing of Orana.

I did everything I could to assist them during September, October and November. I scrupulously respected their wish that these matters should not be raised publicly. In November an internal inquiry was begun by a committee comprising Ms Ruth Prescott of the D.S.S., Mr Alan Bansemer of the S.A. Health Commission, Mr Robert Miles (Chairman of the Board) and Mr Bill Bowden as the parents' representative. The statement today by the Chairman of the Orana Board, Mr Miles , that the inquiry has been completed contradicts his circular to all members stating that he withdraw because of what he alleged was bias by other members of the committee of inquiry. In fact, the inquiry was aborted by his withdrawal. Instructions were issued to the paid staff of Orana by Mr McLachlan not to provide further information to the committee of inquiry or any member of the society.

Parents have become so desperate that they have now asked me to make these matters public in order to reinstate and reinforce urgent Government action. At the same time they are continuing their strenuous efforts to amend the atrocious and gerrymandered constitution. Despite all of these extraordinary irregularities, the Attorney-General has claimed that there is no legal platform on which an official Government inquiry can be instigated. That, of course, is complete nonsense. There are very large sums of Government and public money involved. The Attorney-General can and must now set up an immediate public inquiry. I ask the following questions:
1. Is the Attorney-General aware that the private inquiry was aborted on 4 December?

2. What administrative, legal or legislative action does he propose to resolve the grave difficulties of Orana Inc. and ensure the welfare of 600 intellectually handicapped South Australians cared for by the society, particularly in this Year of the Disabled?
3. Will he take whatever steps are necessary to suspend the Executive Director and the present board and appoint an interim administrator until the parents can reassume control of their society?
4. Will he take whatever other actions are necessary as a matter of the greatest urgency to restore the financial viability, good name and excellent public image formerly enjoyed by the society?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to let any of our people in over there.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Whose responsibility is it to ensure that the guidelines contained in Public Service Board Circular 1980/6 are followed.
(2) What monitoring procedures have been adopted by the Public Service, government departments and statutory authorities.
(3) What action is taken if a suspected breach of the guidelines occurs.
(4) What action may be taken if a retired employee refuses to abide by the guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The onus is on officers themselves to identify conflicts of interest and report the matter to their Chief Officer. Chief Officers have a responsibility to resolve conflicts in line with guidelines. To ensure that staff were informed, when PSB Circular1980/6 was issued the normal distribution of Board Circulars was supplemented by provision to departments of additional copies to distribute to all Second Division officers. Since then, the Board has written to departments a number of times, reminding them of their obligation to notify staff of the circular's contents and emphasising the importance of full implementation. In addition to this departments have taken implementation action including:
reproducing the substance of the circular in departmental staff bulletins and office manuals;
informing staff joining departments of their obligations;
reminding staff retiring or resigning of their post-separation employment guidelines; and
ensuring that selection committees interviewing applicants for promotion inform them of any potential for conflicts of interest.

Additional procedures are applicable where conflicts of interest may arise in relation to post-separation employment. Here, in addition to the responsibility of officers, departments are required under the Circular to identify and designate positions as sensitive where the nature of duties may put the occupants in a special relationship with prospective employers. All First and Second Division officers are considered automatically to be designated sensitive for the purposes of the post-separation employment procedures. Where officers resign or retire from sensitive positions, departments have a responsibility to inform themselves of any prospective employment and take the appropriate steps to ensure that the procedures are followed.

The Circular requires that the Board monitor the implementation and effectiveness of the procedures arising out of the recommendations of the Report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest as they relate to the Australian Public Service. Departments have been requested to record cases which arise and the Board will, at an appropriate time, undertake a general review of the effectiveness of the arrangements; the Board is, of course , in a position to secure the appropriate implementation of procedures in individual cases in which departments inform it of proposed post-separation employment of occupants of sensitive positions.

In a number of cases ministerial assent has been given to post-separation employment of public servants on the basis of certain conditions set by the Minister pursuant to the post-separation employment procedures. Generally speaking it would be neither desirable nor practicable to contemplate some kind of monitoring of the activities of former public servants who have taken up private employment with such conditional assent. In some cases conditions set may be such that their non-observance would be evident to the ex-officer's former department.
The guidelines set out in Board Circular 1980/6 apply only to staff employed under the Public Service Act and do not cover statutory authorities not staffed under the Act.

Were a serious breach of the guidelines by a public servant to come to notice the disciplinary processes of the Public Service Act would be available. In the case of a less serious breach by a public servant counselling might be an adequate way of overcoming any problems.

The guidelines on post-separation employment require that former staff taking up employment which could involve them in conflict of interest should seek the Government's assent before taking up such employment. Once an officer has left the Australian Public Service the disciplinary provisions under the Public Service Act of course do not apply. The Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest recommended (paragraph 13.33) that no additional legislation or penal sanctions be introduced in the post-separation employment area. This recommendation was accepted by the Government.
