QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What guidelines apply to writers grants or fellowships awarded by the Literature Board of the Australia Council.
(2) Under what circumstances is it possible for a person to receive a grant in two consecutive years.
(3) Are there any circumstances in which a means test is applied to applicants for grants or fellowships.
(4) Have persons of substantial means, received large sums from the Literature Board when less affluent young writers are missing out.
(5) On what basis was Mrs M. Dixon of Perth, Western Australia, awarded a second grant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council has advised me as follows-
(1) The Literature Board uses the following guidelines to assess applications from writers. These guidelines are as they appear in the Board publication entitled 'Literature Board 1981'.
'Has the writer the literary talent and persistence to produce a work of high standard?
Would the planned work be retarded or impaired if the grant were not available?
Is the completed work likely to find a publisher and a market ?
The likelihood of eventual publication of works written under grants is a factor considered when the Board examines applications.
The Board awards grants in the following areas: fiction, poetry, playwriting, creative prose. The latter category may include autobiography, essays, histories , travel books and literary criticism.

Projects such as instruction manuals, university theses, guide books, works on the physical sciences and natural sciences, on theology, cooking, medicine or law and projects which are basically aimed at an educational market, are generally considered to be outside the Board's area.
The Board will not normally consider applications from writers for assistance with the publication of their own works'.

(2) I am advised that the only restriction on consecutive grants for writers set down as a statement of policy by the Literature Board relates to fellowships . Literature Board policy on fellowships is as follows:
'Fellowships may be awarded for a maximum of three years but applications for immediate continuation beyond that period will not normally be considered by the Board.'

I am also advised that the Board would not, however, offer a second grant to a writer who had not demonstrated (a) that the first grant was well used and (b) that there is a real need for a second grant.

(3) In awarding its special purpose and general writing grants the Board does not consider an applicant's means but bases its decision on literary criteria, after satisfying itself that a grant is needed as a contribution towards the satisfactory conclusion of a work of genuine literary merit.

Fellowships awarded by the Board are intended as living allowances and may be awarded for periods up to three years. Applicants for fellowships are currently required to supply details of income received from all sources for the previous two financial years and the Board takes this information into consideration in deciding the award of fellowships. Fellowships are not awarded to applicants who have sufficient income to maintain themselves as writers on a full-time basis.
Among the conditions attached by the Board to fellowships is a requirement that recipients give up other full-time employment and restrict part-time employment to be no more than one day per week.
(4) The Literature Board does not have available to it details of all applicants' income. As outlined in answer to (3), only applicants for fellowships are required to provide details of income.

It is therefore not possible to say whether or not persons of substantial means have received grants. Among current holders of fellowships, none have sufficient income (apart from the fellowship) to maintain themselves as writers on a full- time basis.

The Board has always tried to assist the development of young writers who show promise of real talent. This has been done in various ways. Because funds have never been sufficient to meet all meritorious applications, however, some writers (young and old) have failed to obtain assistance which the Board would otherwise wish to offer them.

(5) The Literature Board has no record of a grant, or grants, being awarded to a Mrs M. Dixon of Perth, Western Australia. Two grants have been awarded to Ms Marion Nixon of Perth, but they were not consecutive. The first was a New Writers' Fellowship valued at $10,000, awarded in 1979 to enable Ms Nixon to work during 1980 on two novels; the second fellowship, valued at $17,244, was awarded in October of this year to enable Ms Nixon to work during 1982 on other literary projects.

The two grants were awarded on the basis of the Board's assessment of the work submitted by Ms Nixon to support her application; and on the basis of the Board' s judgement of the literary importance of the proposed work.
In the first case the supporting material included two books previously published by the applicant as well as substantial work-in-progress.

In the second case, the Board had evidence that the first grant had been well used. The applicant had completed the manuscripts of the two novels on which she had worked during her first fellowship. They had been submitted to publishers and appeared to have reasonable prospects of publication. In the meanwhile, a further biographical work, which is expected to be published in 1982, was written. The writer intends to work on another significant novel in 1982, as well as another work of non-fiction. If time allowed, she would also work on another novel.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The isotopic composition of spent HIFAR fuel is not suitable for nuclear weapons use and the quantity of contained plutonium is insufficient to manufacture a weapon.

No plutonium has been separated from spent HIFAR fuel in Australia, and there are no plans to do so. House of Representatives Question No. 5814, answered on 19 August 1980, gives details of the plutonium content of spent HIFAR fuel and the calculated amounts separated and produced elsewhere.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2194) Senator Crichton- Browne asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme (IPTAAS).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has now provided the following information:

The question of advance payments and/or travel vouchers has been considered on a number of occasions in recognition of the difficulty some patients face in meeting the intitial costs of travel and accommodation especially where the patient makes such journeys at fairly regular intervals. However the legislation provides for partial reimbursement after a journey has been completed. This accords with the nature of the scheme as being a form of assistance towards expenditure that is primarily the responsibility of the individual while, at the same time, taking account of the acquittal requirements which involve consideration of the relevant incidents of the journey.

My Department operates the scheme only from offices in the capital cities and any advance payment mechanism would generally require patients to apply to those offices before travel commenced so that such aspects as eligibility and referral to the nearest suitable specialist could be assessed. Subsequent claims would need to be re-examined after completion of journeys to ensure compliance with the original referral, consideration of accommodation allowances, and recovery of the mandatory $20 patient contribution and any other moneys the patient may owe the Commonwealth due to non-compliance with the original referral.

In complementary schemes in the Northern Territory and some States, advance payment proposals have been instituted where, unlike the Commonwealth, they have officers in country areas who may be contacted by persons requiring financial assistance. I understand that all those schemes require the assignment in advance of IPTAAS benefits, where applicable, to the organisation or Government authority that provides the initial funds. In this regard I am pleased to advise that a similar advance payment scheme has recently been introduced in Western Australia following the finalisation of procedural matters with State Government officers. This scheme, which is being operated by the State Department of Community Welfare, enables a patient eligible for IPTAAS benefits to have access to financial assistance for fares and accommodation expenses prior to the commencement of a journey, provided that the relevant matching Commonwealth (IPTAAS) reimbursement is assigned to the State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2272) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the operation of health insurance funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The comparison that the honourable senator makes between the election of delegates and officers of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Railways Union and the boards of management and executives of the Hospital Contribution Fund of Australia and the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Limited, is not valid.

It has generally been traditional for members of unions to determine their representatives by ballot and, on occassions, to determine collectively action to be taken by their representatives to protect or advance their interests. On the other hand, nearly all health funds are either companies limited by guarantee or friendly societies, both of which in relation to representation and conduct of meetings are governed by State legislation. (The two health funds mentioned by the honourable senator are companies limited by guarantee.)

There is a closer analogy between the health funds and general insurers. In return for premiums, contributors and policy holders are entitled to receive benefits, subject to satisfying the terms and conditions relating to the payment of benefits. In the case of health funds, however, policy in relation to the eligibility for and payment of benefits is determined in detail by Commonwealth legislation enacted by Parliament. Health insurance, as is the case with other Government policies, is therefore subject to the democratic process.

Having regard to the closer regulation of health funds by the Government, I consider what is left for management is to conduct health insurance efficiently . In these circumstances, it would be difficult to justify requiring health funds to assume the administrative burden of arranging for millions of contributors to vote for representatives of management and to meet the cost that would be entailed from contributions.
Accordingly, I cannot support the point made by the honourable senator.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation: Telephone Tapping

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2446) Senator Evans asked me a question, without notice, which raised the following substantive issues:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Attorney-General confirm or deny-or remain, I suppose, his usual mute self-the accuracy of the story in last weekend's National Times about the location, manner and frequency of operation of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation telephone tapping facilities in Melbourne and Sydney? Secondly, is it the case, as was claimed in that article, and indeed in a number of other places recently, that Telecom Australia technicians installing or implementing ASIO telephone taps are not in fact shown the authorising warrants, if indeed they exist? If so, what legal justification is claimed to exist for this procedure? Thirdly, what is the Government's attitude toward the extension to State police forces of a much wider range of telepone tapping power for criminal investigation purposes than is recently entitled to be exercised by those forces? Those matters, of course, have been the subject of recent strident claims in meetings of police associations and their commissioners.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

1. In accordance with long standing practice I do not propose to confirm or deny allegations concerning the operational activities of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or the accuracy of media reports relating to such matters.

2. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 provides specifically that copies of warrants issued pursuant to section 9 of the Act must be forwarded as soon as practicable to the Managing Director of the Australian Telecommunications Commission. This requirement is strictly complied with. Instructions to officers of the Commission to take action to enable an interception to be carried out pursuant to such a warrant are given by or on behalf of the Managing Director. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act does not require that an officer of the Commission apart from the Managing Director should sight a copy of the warrant.

3. The honourable senator appears to be under the mistaken belief that State police already have access to interception powers under the Commonwealth legislation. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act powers to intercept telecommunications and telegrams in relation to narcotic enquiries are available only to officers of the Australian Federal Police.

4. The Government is, however, carefully examining the proposals raised in several quarters suggesting the extension of existing powers under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to State police forces as well as a wider range of serious offences for which interception power could be invoked.

5. Any suggestion for the possible extension of interception powers under the Act to State police investigating narcotic offences must be considered in the overall context of the report of the Australian Royal Commission into Drugs ( the Williams Report) including the possible development of uniform drug trafficking legislation. The Government has also noted proposals made, inter alia, at a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers in Hobart in November 1981, for broadening the purposes for which interception powers may be used. The Government remains conscious of the need to preserve the proper balance between the privacy of telecommunications and the public interest in effective law enforcement. I understand that the question of the extension of intercept powers is one of the matters on which the Commonwealth Law Reform Commission proposes to comment in its final report pursuant to the privacy reference. It would, of course, be desirable to have the benefit of the Commission's report on privacy in examining the question of extension of interception powers. I hope that that report will be available later this year to assist the Government in coming to a final view on this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Australia have the technological skills base to meet its total defence equipment needs if the international situation should require this in the 1980s.

(2) Does the Department of Defence or the Department of Industry and Commerce monitor the capabilities of Australian industry relevant to the needs of defence production and do any plans exist for the mobilisation of Australian industry for defence production should the need arise.

(3) Is a scarcity of critical raw materials and a severe shortage of skilled workers in many key phases of production hampering President Reagan's arms ' build up'; if so, is it likely similar shortages will affect any attempt to build up Australia's defence manufacturing base.
(4) Do any Australian firms have the capacity to manufacture high performance jet engines incorporating titanium or advanced composite materials.
(5) Does Australia stockpile raw materials such as: (a) titanium; (b) cobalt; ( c) manganese; (d) tantalum; (e) chromium; (f) platinum; and (g) high quality quartz crystal.

(6) How many: (a) machinists; (b) toolmakers; and (c) diemakers in Australian industry does the Government expect will retire in the next decade and how many of these people will be replaced by new workers.
(7) What is the average age of government-owned machine tools in the munitions industry.
(8) Can Australia depend on even the most benevolent foreign supplier of military equipment when that country cannot supply its own needs, given the delay in the M198 155mm howitzer program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's perspective of Australia's strategic outlook is very different to that implicit in the question. I will not debate the validity of either perspective here. The following answers are shaped by the Government's strategic assessment for the 1980s.
(1) We are developing our defence technological base in accord with current strategic assessments.

(2) Within their respective areas of responsibility, the Department of Defence and the Department of Industry and Commerce monitor and selectively foster Australian industry capabilities relevant to Defence production.
(3) I will not speculate on the U.S. Defence production base but the factors mentioned are always important in any rapid increase in manufacturing activity whether for defence or civil purposes.

(4) Several Australian firms have extensive experience with titanium alloys in the manufacture of components for jet engines; the Government Aircraft Factories have manufacturing experience with carbon fibre composites. This experience ( which will be enhanced during the F/A-18 project) and the knowledge in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation provide a basis from which to develop such a capacity.

(5) Some of the numerous possible forms of these items are stocked in support of defence production. For security reasons the composition and quantities of materials in Defence stockpiles are confidential.
(6) I understand the statistical data enabling detailed response to this question is not available.

I further understand that in 1976 the total number of machinists, toolmakers, and diemakers was an estimated 11,398. At 30 June 1981 there were 54,827 metal trades apprentices in training, an increase of nearly 5 per cent over the previous year. About 40 per cent of metal trades apprentices are in machining, toolmaking and diemaking. A large proportion of these trainees should be available to meet the manpower needs of the 1980s.
(7) The munitions industry presently comprises the eight Government munitions factories.
I understand that based on a recent survey 35 per cent of the plant and machinery inventory of these factories is less than 20 years old and of this nearly 60 per cent is less than 10 years old.

(8) While it would be unrealistic to expect absolute assurance of overseas supply in all circumstances, much has been done to maximise the probability of sustained supply and support from overseas through the negotiation of Memoranda of Understanding and similar agreements. A range of such agreements have been or are currently being negotiated with a number of overseas countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2508) Senator Townley asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Leader ask the Cabinet to consider tabling in the Senate more frequently than every six months a manifest of the flights of VIP aircraft?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Parliament has accepted and acknowledged the present system of tabling the schedule of Royal Australian Air Force Special Purpose flights twice yearly. Under present procedures, the workload involved in preparing the schedule is extremely time consuming, requiring an extension of staff working hours to meet even the six-monthly deadlines. A considerable amount of time and effort is spent cross-checking the flight records with ministerial staff to ensure that they are accurate. It needs to be appreciated that the schedule is prepared from data contained in three different flight records.

Current working arrangements allow preparation of the schedule for tabling, and in particular clearance of any discrepancies, to be undertaken whilst Parliament is in recess. Any additional tablings would overlap Parliamentary Sittings and conflict with the heavy workloads already borne by staff at these times.
In the circumstances, I cannot agree to any extension to the present system of tabling the schedule of RAAF special purpose flights twice yearly.
